12-13 HS1 Q8.question: Which of the following is true?

options.A: Resistance increases with the number of nodes of Ranvier in a nerve fibre.
options.B: Resistance increases with degree of myelination of a nerve fibre.
options.C: Resistance increases with the radius of a nerve fibre.
options.D: Plasma membrane is a good insulator because it offers low resistance to ion movement.
options.E: Plasma membrane is a fairly good insulator because it offers high resistance to ion movement.

12-13 HS1 Q8.explanation:
*Plasma membrane is a fairly good insulator because it offers high resistance to ion movement.*  
  
A. Resistance increases with the number of nodes of Ranvier in a nerve fibre. *Incorrect*  
Should be decreases instead of increases.  
Nodes of Ranvier refers to the places at axons where it is not myelinated.  
At that place, it has the highest concentration of voltage-gated Na<sup>+</sup> and K<sup>+</sup> channels.  

B. Resistance increases with degree of myelination of a nerve fibre. *Incorrect*  
Should be decreases instead of increases.  
This is because myelination will increase the resistance of ion fluxes, thus the depolarizing current can flow with much less effect from K<sup>+</sup> efflux (which dissipates the depolarizing current).  
In fact, a new action potential can be generated at a further position from the original place for initiation of action potential, hence the velocity of action potential travels faster (lower resistance).  

C. Resistance increases with the radius of a nerve fibre. *Incorrect*  
Should be decreases instead of increases. (By Cable property)  
Note that the larger the radius, than the axoplasm will allow lower resistance of the Na<sup>+</sup> depolarizing current to flow along the axon (longitudinally)  

D. Plasma membrane is a good insulator because it offers low resistance to ion movement. *Incorrect*  
It offers high resistance to ion movement. This also hinted that E is the correct option.

12-13 HS1 Q10.question: Which of the following about Na<sup>+</sup>/K<sup>+</sup> ATPase pump is correct?

options.A: 3 K<sup>+</sup> ions out and 1 Na<sup>+</sup> ion in.
options.B: 3 K<sup>+</sup> ions out and 2 Na<sup>+</sup> ions in.
options.C: 1 K<sup>+</sup> ion out and 3 Na<sup>+</sup> ions in.
options.D: 2 K<sup>+</sup> ions in and 2 Na<sup>+</sup> ions out.
options.E: 2 K<sup>+</sup> ions in and 3 Na<sup>+</sup> ions out.

12-13 HS1 Q10.explanation:
*2 K<sup>+</sup> ions in and 3 Na<sup>+</sup> ions out.*  
  
Note that potassium ions will tend to diffuse out of the cell, while sodium ions tend to diffuse in the cell, both using their respective leak channels.  
The pump uses ATP and helps to maintain the concentration gradient of K<sup>+</sup> and Na<sup>+</sup> across the cell membrane (imbalance charges), i.e. compensating for the loss of intracellular K<sup>+</sup> and extracellular Na<sup>+</sup>.  
As a result, the resting membrane potential can be maintained.  
  
Mechanisms for the Na<sup>+</sup>\-K<sup>+</sup> ATPase pump:

1.  3 Na<sup>+</sup> binds to the intracellular binding site.
2.  This triggers ATP to be hydrolyzed (enzymatic reaction) and the phosphate group binds to the receptor also, inducing a conformational change that eventually shifts the 3 Na<sup>+</sup> to ECF, then released to ECF.
3.  2 K<sup>+</sup> binds to the extracellular binding site.
4.  This triggers the dephosphorylation of the pump. A conformational change is induced that eventually shifts the 2 K<sup>+</sup> to ICF, then released to ICF.

12-13 HS1 Q11.question: If the resting membrane potential is -100mV and the sodium equilibrium potential is +40mV, what is the value of the electrochemical gradient (i.e. driving force acting on the sodium ions)? Choose one correct answer.
12-13 HS1 Q11.explanation:
*\-140 (mV)*  
  
Electrochemical force = Chemical force + Electrical force  
Chemical force is the reverse of equilibrium potential, while electrical force is due to the membrane potential.  
Hence force = V<sub>M</sub> – E<sub>Na</sub> = -100 + (-40) = -140 mV

12-13 HS1 Q12.question: According to Ohm’s law, increase in voltage increases with
12-13 HS1 Q12.explanation:
*Resistance increases current increase*

  
By Ohm’s law, V=IR.

12-13 HS1 Q13.question: During the rising phase of action potential, voltage gated

options.E: Na ion channel close, K ion channel open.

12-13 HS1 Q13.explanation:
*Na<sup>+</sup> ion channel open.*  
  
At the depolarization phase, voltage-gated sodium channels open so that the sodium influx creates depolarization.  
  
Process of depolarization:  
1. Due to synaptic potential (EPSP), then some of the voltage-gated sodium channels open, some sodium ions influx, little depolarization is recorded due to increase permeability to Na<sup>+</sup>.  
2. Depolarization will stimulate the opening of more voltage-gated sodium channels. Eventually, if the depolarization reaches beyond the threshold, note that there is a positive feedback loop in which enough voltage-gated sodium channels open. Generation of action potential is recorded.

12-13 HS1 Q14.question: Why resting membrane potential depends greatly on the equilibrium potassium potential?

options.A: K<sup>+</sup> is the major extracellular ion in excitable cells.
options.B: Permeability of Na<sup>+</sup> is low except for rising phase of action potential.
options.D: The permeability of membrane to K<sup>+</sup> is higher, including that of Na<sup>+</sup>.

12-13 HS1 Q14.explanation:
*The permeability of membrane to K<sup>+</sup> ion is higher, including that of Na<sup>+</sup> ion.*

  
Resting membrane potential is the weighted equilibrium potential of all the ions contributing to the development of the membrane voltage (Na<sup>+</sup>, K<sup>+</sup> and Cl<sup>-</sup>).  
The higher the permeability of the ion, then the greater its contribution it is to the resting membrane potential. *Goldman equation*  
It should be noted that the permeability of K<sup>+ </sup> is higher due to higher concentration of K<sup>+</sup> leak channels distributed across the cell membrane (compared to Na<sup>+</sup> leak channels).

12-13 HS1 Q15.question: Nernst equation and movement of ions across the plasma membrane. Which of the following is false?

options.A: Nernst potential can only be positive.

12-13 HS1 Q15.explanation:
*Nernst potential can only be positive.*

  
Membrane potential can also be negative.  
Example: E<sub>K</sub> is around -90 mV.

12-13 HS2 Q24.question: Which part of the brain is responsible for receiving sensory information for pain and temperature?
12-13 HS2 Q24.explanation:
*Parietal*

  
A. Cerebellum is for maintaining body balance, coordinating muscle contraction and memory of skilled movements. *MEDU1110*  
  
B. Temporal lobe is for auditory purpose (mainly). *MEDU1110*  
  
C. Brainstem is for attaching of cranial nerves, involved in sleep-wake cycle, main cardiovascular and respiratory center etc. *MEDU1110*  
  
E. Frontal lobe is the main motor area. *MEDU1110*

13-14 HS1 Q42.question: Which of the following would cause a rapid decrease in movement of K<sup>+</sup> out of a neuronal cell?

options.E: Inhibiting the activity of Na<sup>+</sup>/K<sup>+</sup>-ATPase pumps

13-14 HS1 Q42.explanation:
*Hyperpolarization of the membrane*

  
Electrochemical driving force = V<sub>M</sub> – E<sub>K</sub>    V<sub>M</sub> > E<sub>K</sub>  
The decrease in K<sup>+</sup> efflux can be caused by decrease in V<sub>M</sub> or the increase in E<sub>K</sub>.  
Only option B results in a rapid decrease in V<sub>M</sub>, thus causing a rapid decrease in movement of K<sup>+</sup> out of the cell.  
A. Will also result in decrease in V<sub>M</sub> but the effect is much slower than that in option B.  
C. Will passively increase V<sub>M</sub>.  
D. Will increase V<sub>M</sub> thus increase K<sup>+</sup> efflux.

13-14 HS1 Q43.question: When the extracellular Na<sup>+</sup> is decreased by half,

options.A: Decrease in equilibrium potential of K<sup>+</sup>
options.C: The peak of action potential is lower

13-14 HS1 Q43.explanation:
*The peak of action potential is lower*

  
A. E<sub>K</sub> is independent of the sodium ion concentration gradient.  
  
B. Threshold remains much or less the same, or increases slightly, but not lowered.  
  
C. The amplitude of the action potential will be lowered due to less Na<sup>+</sup> influx.  
Factors affecting the size of action potential:  
\->Ion concentration gradient across cell membrane  
\->Type and density of the ion channels embedded in the cell membrane  
\->Dynamics of the ion channels when they are in open and closed state during excitation and recovery (or simply, their properties)  

D and E. Rate of depolarization and hyperpolarization will remain much or less the same. This is because the voltage-gated sodium channels are already inactivated right after depolarization, making the sodium concentration in ECF less important (especially during the absolute refractory period)

13-14 HS1 Q44.question: Which of the following will generate IPSP?

options.A: Decreased activity of the Na<sup>+</sup>/K<sup>+</sup> ATPase

13-14 HS1 Q44.explanation:
*Increased membrane permeability of K<sup>+</sup>*  
  
Note that for inhibitory postsynaptic potential, the effect should be hyperpolarization so that it is further away from the threshold.  

A. The Na<sup>+</sup>/K<sup>+</sup> ATPase is mainly responsible for maintaining the concentration gradient of Na<sup>+</sup> and K<sup>+</sup> across the cell membrane when the cell is *at rest*. Decreasing its activity won’t result in significant hyperpolarization.  
  
B. This decreases Cl<sup>-</sup> influx hence result in depolarization.  
  
C. K<sup>+</sup> efflux will increase, resulting in hyperpolarization.  
  
D and E. Both result in the increase of influx of cations, resulting in depolarization. (EPSP generated)

13-14 HS1 Q45.question: Which of the following description can be applied to both graded potential and action potential?

options.A: They are of stereotypical size and shape.
options.B: They can be conducted without decrement.
options.D: They can give rise to depolarization.
options.E: They do not have a refractory period.

13-14 HS1 Q45.explanation:
*They can give rise to depolarization.*  
  
A. Only action potential is of stereotypical size and shape, note for graded potential. For graded potential, the stronger the stimulus, the greater the amplitude the potential is.  
  
B. Graded potential is transmitted with decrement as the potential spreads passively towards the soma and axon hillock. Meanwhile, action potential will undergo self-regeneration (The depolarization current carried by Na<sup>+</sup> at the axoplasm will stimulate the adjacent nascent region to depolarize, generating another action potential).  
  
C. Action potential cannot be summated due to the presence of an absolute refractory period. In this period, all voltage-gated Na<sup>+</sup> channels are inactivated, making it impossible to initiate another depolarization event.  
  
E. Action potential has refractory period.

13-14 HS1 Q46.question: Which of the following is the best account of the occurrence of relative refractory period after the action potential period?

options.A: Activation gate of Na<sup>+</sup> ion channels is closed
options.B: Opening of K<sup>+</sup> ion channel begins
options.C: Driving force for the inflow of Na<sup>+</sup> ion decreases
options.D: Driving force for the outflow of K<sup>+</sup> increases
options.E: Na<sup>+</sup> ion channels are partially inactivated

13-14 HS1 Q46.explanation:
*Na<sup>+</sup> ion channels are partially inactivated*  
  
The presence of a relatively refractory period is attributed to some Na<sup>+</sup> channels are still inactivated, but some are activated again (returned to their basal closed state).  
As there is still  
\->K<sup>+</sup> efflux opposing the depolarization effect due to Na<sup>+</sup> influx  
\->not all Na<sup>+</sup> channels are activated  
A larger stimulus (increased threshold) is required for the generation of another action potential during the relative refractory period.

13-14 HS1 Q59.question: Some neurons in the sympathetic nerve terminate on the sinoatrial node cells. These neurons produce norepinephrine, which ultimately increases the cardiac output. This is an example of
13-14 HS1 Q59.explanation:
*Neuronal control*  
  
Effect is mediated by the nervous system through synaptic connections.

14-15 HS1 Q1.question: Which condition best describes a neuron at its resting state?

options.A: Chemical and electrical gradients are in opposite direction for Ca<sup>2+</sup>
options.B: Chemical and electrical gradients are in opposite direction for Cl<sup>-</sup>
options.C: Chemical and electrical gradients are in same direction for Na<sup>+</sup>
options.D: Chemical and electrical gradients are in same direction for K<sup>+</sup>
options.E: Electrical gradients for Na<sup>+ </sup> and K<sup>+</sup> are in opposite direction

14-15 HS1 Q1.explanation:
*Chemical and electrical gradients are in same direction for Na+*  
  
Note that the gradient produces a force, which has the same direction as the gradient.

|  | Electrical force | Chemical force |
| -------- | -------- | -------- |
| Ca<sup>2+</sup> | Pointing inside the cell | Pointing inside the cell |
| Na<sup>+</sup> | Pointing inside the cell | Pointing inside the cell |
| K<sup>+</sup> | Pointing inside the cell | Pointing outside the cell |
| Cl<sup>-</sup> | Pointing outside the cell | Pointing inside the cell |
  
B. This is also a correct option, but I don’t think it’s the best option, since K<sup>+</sup> and Na<sup>+</sup> are the main characters.

14-15 HS1 Q2.question: In excitable cells, depolarization that occurs after an action potential is contributed mostly by which of the following events?

14-15 HS1 Q4.question: Which of the following statements is TRUE about the absolute refractory period?

options.A: High permeability for K<sup>+</sup> is responsible for the refractoriness of absolute refractory period.
options.B: The absolute refractory period roughly coincides with after-hyperpolarization.
options.C: Inactivation of voltage-gated Na<sup>+</sup> channels are the major cause for absolute refractory period.
options.D: During the absolute refractory period, second action potential is elected provided that a higher-than-normal stimulus is triggered.
options.E: The absolute refractory period is shorter if voltage-gated K<sup>+</sup> channels are blocked.

14-15 HS1 Q4.explanation:
*Inactivation of voltage-gated Na+ channels are the major cause for absolute refractory period.*

  
When voltage-gated Na<sup>+</sup> channels are opened, membrane permeability to sodium ions greatly increase, eventually resulting in depolarization of the membrane, which also causes the inactivation of the voltage-gated Na<sup>+</sup> channels.  
Due to a very high proportion of Na<sup>+</sup> channels being inactivated, it is impossible for another upshoot/ depolarization, i.e. impossible to generate another action potential, during the absolute refractory period.  
  
A and E. The absolute refractory period is not related to K<sup>+</sup>.  
  
B. Should coincide with depolarization and repolarization, but not hyperpolarization.  
  
D. It is impossible to generate another action potential during the absolute refractory period.  
Second action potential is elected provided that a higher-than-normal stimulus is triggered occurs during the relative refractory period.

14-15 HS1 Q5.question: Inhibitory synaptic potential is caused by…

options.A: Depolarization of post synaptic membrane by opening of Ca<sup>2+</sup> channel
options.B: Depolarization of post synaptic membrane by closing of Cl<sup>-</sup> channel
options.C: Depolarization of post synaptic membrane by opening of Na<sup>+</sup> channel
options.D: Hyperpolarization of post synaptic membrane by opening of Cl<sup>-</sup> channel
options.E: Hyperpolarization of post synaptic membrane by opening of K<sup>+</sup> channel

14-15 HS1 Q5.explanation:
*Hyperpolarization of post synaptic membrane by opening of K<sup>+</sup> channel*  
  
Note that for inhibitory postsynaptic potential, the effect should be hyperpolarization so that it is further away from the threshold, ruling out A, B and C.  
Both D and E can result in hyperpolarization of the cell membrane.

Yet, Cl<sup>-</sup> ions are already passively distributed across the cell membrane, hence V<sub>M</sub> actually close to E<sub>Cl</sub>, making the electrochemical driving force on Cl<sup>-</sup> small. Hence the increase in membrane permeability to Cl<sup>-</sup> through opening of Cl<sup>-</sup> channels won’t result in significant hyperpolarization.  
It should be noted that Cl⁻ channels can still contribute to IPSP in some cases.

14-15 HS1 Q6.question: Which part in the neuron is most important in integrating messages and generating signals?
14-15 HS1 Q6.explanation:
*Axon hillock*  
  
Axon hillock helps the summation of synaptic potential (which contain IPSPs and/or EPSPs) (temporal and spatial). This results in the integration of synaptic potential.  
If the integrated potential is higher than the threshold, then an action potential will be generated in the spike initiation zone/trigger zone.

14-15 HS1 Q7.question: Autonomic nervous system is

options.A: Afferent division of the peripheral nervous system that receives inputs from the somatic senses.
options.B: Afferent division of the peripheral nervous system that receives inputs from the special senses.
options.C: Afferent division of the peripheral nervous system that receives inputs from the visceral senses
options.D: Efferent division of the peripheral nervous system that outputs to voluntary muscles
options.E: Efferent division of the peripheral nervous system that outputs to the involuntary muscles

14-15 HS1 Q7.explanation:
*Efferent division of the peripheral nervous system that outputs to the involuntary muscles*  
  
Note that the ANS is divided into the sympathetic (fight or flight) and parasympathetic (rest or digest) system.

14-15 HS1 Q8.question: Which of the following has a similar function as oligodendrocytes?
14-15 HS1 Q8.explanation:
*Schwann cells*  
  
One oligodendrocyte can myelinated multiple axons (in CNS), while each Schwann cell only myelinate one internodal segment (in PNS).

14-15 HS1 Q9.question: The gray matter of the spinal cord primarily contains:
14-15 HS1 Q9.explanation:
*Cell body of nerve fibre*  
  
The nucleus of the cell body gives the dark colour.

14-15 HS1 Q10.question: Which of the following represents an example of somatic senses?
14-15 HS1 Q10.explanation:
*Touch*  
  
Somatic senses refers to senses from the skin surface, muscles and joints (proprioception).  
There are three types of senses, namely special, somatic and visceral senses.  
Visceral: From the internal organs *such as blood pressure, fullness of bladder and hunger*  
Somatic: Skin surface, muscles and joints  
Special: Vision, Sound, Balance/Equilibrium, Smell, Taste

14-15 HS1 Q11.question: Which of the following part is where the most cranial nerves come out from CNS?
14-15 HS1 Q11.explanation:
*Brain stem*  
  
CN III to CN XII comes out from the brainstem of CNS. CN I (olfactory) and CN II (optic) arises from the forebrain hence they belong to the CNS, but not the PNS.

14-15 HS1 Q12.question: Which of the following is absent in the node of Ranvier of a myelinated nerve?
14-15 HS1 Q12.explanation:
*Myelin sheath*  
  
Node of Ranvier is the place where the axon is unprotected by myelin sheath. It has the highest concentration of voltage gated K<sup>+</sup> channel and Voltage gated Na<sup>+</sup> channel.

15-16 HS1 Q11.question: Which of the following gives an example of special senses?
15-16 HS1 Q11.explanation:
*Vision*  
  
Somatic senses refers to senses from the skin surface, muscles and joints (proprioception).  
There are three types of senses, namely special, somatic and visceral senses.  
Visceral: From the internal organs *such as blood pressure, fullness of bladder, hunger and core body temperature*  
Somatic: Skin surface, muscles and joints *such as peripheral body temperature*  
Special: Vision, Sound, Balance/Equilibrium, Smell, Taste

15-16 HS1 Q12.question: Which of the following glia cells line the wall of ventricles in the brain and central canal in the spinal cord and help in the circulation of cerebrospinal fluid?

15-16 HS1 Q13.question: In peripheral nervous system,

options.A: Cranial nerve contains both sympathetic and parasympathetic nerve fibre
options.B: Cranial nerve contains both sensory and motor nerve fibre
options.C: Cranial nerve contains either sensory or motor, nerve fibre
options.D: Spinal nerve contains both sensory and motor nerve fibre
options.E: Spinal nerve contains either sensory or motor nerve fibre

15-16 HS1 Q13.explanation:
*Spinal nerve contains both sensory and motor nerve fibre*  
  
Spinal nerve are **mixed** nerves, i.e. they contain both sensory and motor nerve fiber.  
Note that the sensory neuron is pseudo-unipolar/unipolar, while the motor neuron is multipolar neuron.  
Sensory neuron will have its axon reaching the dorsal horn of the gray matter of spinal cord, while the motor neuron arises from the ventral horn (somatic motor) or lateral horn (visceral motor).  
In the PNS, cranial nerves only contain sensory nerve fiber. (CN I and CN II are both sensory nerves)

15-16 HS1 Q14.question: Which of the following best describes the PNS?

options.A: Sensory nerve is multipolar and afferent to CNS
options.B: Motor nerve is bipolar and effector to CNS
options.C: Sensory nerve is bipolar and afferent to CNS
options.D: Motor nerve is multipolar and CNS to afferent

15-16 HS1 Q14.explanation:
*Sensory pseudo-unipolar afferent to CNS*

  
Motor nerve is multipolar and efferent.  
Sensory nerve is pseudo-unipolar and afferent.  
Seldom in our body can we find bipolar neurons.

15-16 HS1 Q15.question: Autonomic nervous system constitutes the which part of the homeostatic system?

16-17 HS1 Q33.question: In determining the equilibrium potential for a particular ion, which of the following will give rise to a higher absolute value when calculated using the Nernst equation?

options.A: Higher charge density of the ion
options.B: Higher concentration difference of the ion across the cell membrane
options.C: Higher ionic radius of the ion
options.D: Higher number of charges carried by the ion (i.e. higher valency)
options.E: Higher permeability of the cell membrane to the ion

16-17 HS1 Q33.explanation:
*Higher concentration difference of the ion across the cell membrane*

Note that

$E = \frac{RT}{zF} \ln{\frac{[I]_o}{[I]_i}} = \frac{61.5}{z} \log{\frac{[I]_o}{[I]_i}} mV$

Where

E = Equilibrium potential  
R = Universal gas constant (8.31 J K<sup>-1</sup> mol <sup>-1</sup>)  
T = Absolute temperature in K<sup>o</sup>
F = Faraday’s constant 9.65 x 10<sup>4</sup> C mol<sup>-1</sup>
Z = Valency of the ion (+ for cations, – for anions)
\[I\]<sub>o </sub> \= Ion concentration outside cell, \[I\]<sub>i </sub> \= Ion concentration inside cell

  
It can be easily observed that the higher concentration gradient of the ion will result in a higher |E<sub>ion</sub>|.  
If the question concerns E<sub>ion </sub> instead of |E<sub>ion</sub>|, then note that a higher concentration difference of the ion across the cell membrane will not necessarily give a higher E<sub>ion</sub>. But now only the magnitude is concerned, so B is the correct answer.

16-17 HS1 Q34.question: Which of the following change causes hyperpolarization of membrane?
16-17 HS1 Q34.explanation:
*Increase in K<sup>+</sup> permeability*

  
Hyperpolarization means that V<sub>M</sub> decreases.  
  
A. This increases Na<sup>+</sup> influx hence induce depolarization.  
  
B. This increases K<sup>+</sup> efflux hence induce hyperpolarization.  
  
C and E. These increase influx of cations, hence induce depolarization.  
  
D. This decreases the chemical force on K<sup>+</sup> (which is pointing outside of the cell). As a result, K<sup>+</sup> efflux decreases, causing depolarization.

16-17 HS1 Q35.question: Which of the following changes would result in the generation of IPSP?
16-17 HS1 Q35.explanation:
*Increased permeability of K<sup>+</sup>*  
  
Note that for inhibitory postsynaptic potential, the effect should be hyperpolarization so that it is further away from the threshold.  

A. The Na<sup>+</sup>/K<sup>+</sup> ATPase is mainly responsible for maintaining the concentration gradient of Na<sup>+</sup> and K<sup>+</sup> across the cell membrane when the cell is *at rest*. Decreasing its activity won’t result in significant hyperpolarization.  
  
B. This decreases Cl<sup>-</sup> influx hence result in depolarization.  
  
C and E. Both result in the increase of influx of cations, resulting in depolarization. (EPSP generated)  
  
D. K<sup>+</sup> efflux will increase, resulting in hyperpolarization.

16-17 HS1 Q36.question: The following graph shows the action potential of a neuron. At which of the following labelled point would there be the smallest driving force of Na?
16-17 HS1 Q36.explanation:
*3 (maximum potential)*  
  
Note that at maximum potential, the V<sub>M</sub> is highest (around +30 mV), then the V<sub>M</sub> is closest to E<sub>Na</sub>. Hence the electrochemical driving force on Na<sup>+</sup> is the smallest.

16-17 HS1 Q37.question: Which of the following will most likely lead to a decreased amplitude of action potential in a neuron?

options.A: Decreasing the strength of the stimulus
options.B: Increasing the extracellular concentration of Na<sup>+</sup>
options.C: Increasing the membrane permeability to K<sup>+</sup>
options.D: Lowering the resting membrane potential to a more negative value
options.E: Triggering the generation of action potential during the relative refractory period

16-17 HS1 Q37.explanation:
*Triggering the generation of action potential during the relative refractory period*  
  
A. The strength of the stimulus determines the frequency of generation of action potential, but the amplitude of action potential becomes unchanged as long as the stimulus strength is larger than the threshold but not subthreshold.  
  
B. This will increase the amplitude as the depolarization effect is stronger.  
  
C. This is not the best answer. Note that there are 2 methods to increase the membrane permeability to K<sup>+</sup>.  
   1) By increasing the density of the K<sup>+</sup> leak channels. Note that the leak channels actually do not contribute much to the repolarization, as well can see during the depolarization process. If the significance of leak channels is really that large, then why can the cell membrane still undergo depolarization? The increase in K<sup>+</sup> leak channels will only result in more negative RMP.  
   2) By increasing the density of the voltage-gated K<sup>+</sup> leak channels. Note that the voltage-gated ion channels have not opened during the depolarization phase, i.e. permeability only increases during the repolarization phase, hence not reducing the amplitude of the action potential.  
  
D. Amplitude of the action potential remains unchanged.  
  
E. Note that less Na<sup>+</sup> will have influx into the cell due to less voltage-gated ion channels activated during the relative refractory period, then result in less depolarization. Hence the amplitude will be smaller.  
  
**\*Yet, most senior’s sources said that C should be the correct answer. For instance:**  
![](img/16-17_HS1_Q37_1754584449719.png)  
So please decide yourself which answer is correct.

16-17 HS1 Q38.question: In the peripheral nervous system, the myelin sheath of the axon of myelinated nerve is provided by which of the following neuroglial cell?

16-17 HS1 Q39.question: From which region of the central nervous system do the cranial nerves arise from?
16-17 HS1 Q39.explanation:
*Brainstem*  
  
Note that CN I and CN II (olfactory and optic nerve respectively) arises from the forebrain.  
These two pairs of nerve belong to the CNS.  
Other cranial nerves belong to the PNS.

16-17 HS1 Q40.question: In a myelinated nerve, voltage-gated Na<sup>+</sup> channels concentrated in

16-17 HS1 Q41.question: Continuous conduction of nerve impulse refers to

options.A: Influx of Na<sup>+</sup> at the nodes of Ranvier
options.B: Propagation of action potential along the axon of an unmyelinated neuron
options.D: Spread of electrical potential from dendrite to soma
options.E: Spread of action potential from dendrites to soma

16-17 HS1 Q41.explanation:
*Propagation of action potential along the axon of an unmyelinated neuron*  
  
Note that for continuous conduction, there are a few processes.  
1. Generation of the action potential in the <u>spike initiation zone</u>.  
2. The <u>depolarizing current carried by Na<sup>+</sup> influx</u> will <u>spread to the adjacent membrane</u> (nascent) <u>region</u> and <u>depolarizes it to the threshold level</u>, triggering the generation of a new action potential.  
- This is a self-regenerative process, and that it involves the <u>spread of charges over short distance continuously</u>. Hence the action potential is described as *non-decremental* unlike graded potentials.  
  
Meanwhile for myelinated axon, this is saltatory conduction. Action potential are induced to generate only at the Node of Ranvier and propagate faster by <u>jumping from node to node</u>.  
The depolarizing effect from the Na<sup>+</sup> influx is not counteracted by K<sup>+</sup> efflux along the internodal region due to two reasons:  
1) High resistance to ion fluxes due to higher resistance of the myelin sheath  
2) Low density of voltage-gated K<sup>+ </sup> channels (or even absence)  
Hence, fewer action potentials need to be generated, resulting in quicker transmission of the action potential.  
Meanwhile nodes of Ranvier are exposed to extracellular fluid, having the highest concentration of voltage-gated K<sup>+</sup> and Na<sup>+</sup> channels (and the Na<sup>+</sup>/K<sup>+</sup>\-ATPase) for generation of action potential.

17-18 HS1 Q11.question: In a typical neuron, what is most likely to occur if the voltage-gated K<sup>+</sup> channels are blocked?

options.A: Amplitude of an action potential decreases
options.C: The membrane takes longer to depolarize
options.D: The threshold potential becomes more positive
options.E: The resting membrane potential becomes less negative

17-18 HS1 Q11.explanation:
*The refractory period becomes longer*  
  
A. Amplitude of the action potential should remain much or less the same, or a little bit larger than normal because the K<sup>+</sup> efflux occurs at a later time.  
  
B. True. Note that it takes a longer time for repolarization due to slower K<sup>+</sup> efflux due to blocked voltage-gated K<sup>+</sup> channels. The refractory period will increases because the Na<sup>+</sup> channels will only be reactivated after a longer period of time when the membrane potential becomes more negative.  
  
C. The time for depolarization is unchanged, as it mainly concerns the rate of Na<sup>+</sup> influx only.  
  
D. Threshold potential is unchanged.  
  
E. Resting membrane potential is also unchanged. It only takes a longer time for the membrane potential to approach the resting membrane potential, but the value itself is not altered.

17-18 HS1 Q12.question: The increased permeability to which ion(s) of membrane will give rise to a greatest depolarisation?
17-18 HS1 Q12.explanation:
*Sodium and calcium*  
  
These will increase influx of cations hence result in greatest depolarization.

17-18 HS1 Q13.question: Which of the following would most likely results in a decreased amplitude of action potential in a neuron?

options.A: Decreasing the strength of the stimulus
options.D: Lowering the resting membrane potential to a more negative value
options.E: Triggering the generation of action potential during the relative refractory period

17-18 HS1 Q13.explanation:
*Triggering the generation of action potential during the relative refractory period*  
  
A. It must be emphasized again that the strength of the stimulus will only affect the frequency, but not the amplitude of action potential.  
  
B. This will increase Na<sup>+</sup> influx during depolarization and will result in a greater depolarization effect hence increased amplitude of action potential.  
  
C. This is not the best answer. Note that there are 2 methods to increase the membrane permeability to K<sup>+</sup>.  
   1) By increasing the density of the K<sup>+</sup> leak channels. Note that the leak channels actually do not contribute much to the repolarization, as well can see during the depolarization process. If the significance of leak channels is really that large, then why can the cell membrane still undergo depolarization?  
   2) By increasing the density of the voltage-gated K<sup>+</sup> leak channels. Note that the voltage-gated ion channels have not opened during the depolarization phase, i.e. permeability only increases during the repolarization phase, hence not reducing the amplitude of the action potential.  

D. Amplitude of the action potential remains unchanged.  
  
E. Note that less Na<sup>+</sup> will have influx into the cell due to less voltage-gated ion channels activated during the relative refractory period, then result in less depolarization. Hence the amplitude will be smaller.

17-18 HS1 Q14.question: The Na<sup>+</sup> chemical gradient across nerve cell membrane...

options.A: is an important determinant of the resting membrane potential.
options.B: is maintained by the negative resting membrane potential.
options.C: drops significantly after an action potential
options.D: provides energy for secondary active transport.

17-18 HS1 Q14.explanation:
*provides energy for secondary active transport*  
  
A. Note that resting membrane potential is the weighted average of the equilibrium potential of the ions contributing to the cell membrane. The higher the conductance of the ion then the higher the influence on the resting membrane potential.  
As P<sub>K</sub> > P<sub>Na</sub> hence K<sup>+</sup> is an important determinant of the resting membrane potential but not Na<sup>+</sup>.  
  
B. The chemical gradient is determined by the Na<sup>+</sup>/K<sup>+</sup> ATPase.  
Note that potassium ions will tend to diffuse out of the cell, while sodium ions tend to diffuse in the cell, both using their respective leak channels.  
The pump uses ATP and helps to maintain the concentration gradient of K<sup>+</sup> and Na<sup>+</sup> across the cell membrane (imbalance charges), i.e. compensating for the loss of intracellular K<sup>+</sup> and extracellular Na<sup>+</sup> so as the maintain the concentration gradient of sodium ions across the cell membrane.  
  
C. The ion concentration gradient will not be significantly altered by the end of action potential.  
  
D. The Na<sup>+</sup> chemical gradient will result in sodium ions moving down the concentration gradient which couples with the moving of another particle moving against the concentration gradients using symporter/antiporter (cotransporter) by secondary active transport.  
Put differently, a particle moves against its concentration gradient by using the potential energy of Na<sup>+</sup> chemical gradient.  
E.g. Sodium-glucose symporter to transport glucose against its concentration gradient, accompanied with the Na<sup>+</sup> moving down its concentration gradient by secondary active transport.  
  
E. Irrelevant.

17-18 HS1 Q15.question: In the central nervous system, which of the following ganglia cell is responsible for the removal of pathogen, waste and debris?
17-18 HS1 Q15.explanation:
*Microglia*  
  
It is also known as brain macrophages, and it is very active in areas in brain which is damaged.

17-18 HS1 Q16.question: Continuous conduction of nerve impulses refers to...

options.A: Influx of Na+ ions through voltage-gated Na+ channel on node of Ranvier
options.B: Propagation of action potential along the axon of an unmyelinated neuron
options.C: Spread of electrical potential of Na+ to next node of Ranvier
options.D: Spread of electrical potential of Na+ from dendrite to soma
options.E: Spread of action potential from dendrites to soma

17-18 HS1 Q16.explanation:
*Propagation of action potential along the axon of an unmyelinated neuron*  
  
Note that for continuous conduction, there are a few processes.  
1. Generation of the action potential in the <u>spike initiation zone</u>.  
2. The <u>depolarizing current carried by Na</u><sup><u>+</u></sup> <u> influx</u> will <u>spread to the adjacent membrane</u> (nascent) <u>region</u> and <u>depolarizes it to the threshold level</u>, triggering the generation of a new action potential.  

\-This is a self-regenerative process, and that it involves the <u>spread of charges over short distance continuously</u>. Hence the action potential is described as *non-decremental* unlike graded potentials.  
  
Meanwhile for myelinated axon, this is saltatory conduction. Action potential are induced to generate only at the Node of Ranvier and propagate faster by <u>jumping from node to node</u>.  
The depolarizing effect from the Na<sup>+</sup> influx is not counteracted by K<sup>+</sup> efflux along the internodal region due to two reasons:  
1) High resistance to ion fluxes due to higher resistance of the myelin sheath  
2) Low density of voltage-gated K<sup>+ </sup> channels (or even absence)  
Hence, fewer action potentials need to be generated, resulting in quicker transmission of the action potential.  
Meanwhile nodes of Ranvier are exposed to extracellular fluid, having the highest concentration of voltage-gated K<sup>+</sup> and Na<sup>+</sup> channels (and the Na<sup>+</sup>/K<sup>+</sup>\-ATPase) for generation of action potential.

17-18 HS1 Q17.question: The speed along the axon is directly related to...

options.E: the number of nodes of Ranvier.

17-18 HS1 Q17.explanation:
*the diameter of axon*  
  
Note that the larger the diameter of axon, then the resistance of the axoplasm to longitudinal flow of Na<sup>+</sup> depolarizing current is lower, resulting in higher speed of signal transmission along the axon.

17-18 HS1 Q18.question: In PNS, which of the following is true?

options.A: Cranial nerves include parasympathetic and sympathetic nerves
options.B: Cranial nerves include both sensory and motor nerves
options.C: Cranial nerves include either sensory and motor nerves
options.D: Spinal nerves include both sensory and motor nerves
options.E: Spinal nerves include either sensory or motor nerves

17-18 HS1 Q18.explanation:
*Spinal nerves include both sensory and motor nerves*  
  
In PNS, there are spinal nerves and CN I, CN II.  
Both CN I and CN II are cranial nerves which are sensory nerves. They do not contain parasympathetic or sympathetic nerve fibers.  
Spinal nerves are mixed nerves, with both sensory and motor nerves.

18-19 HS2 Q20.question: Which of the following would most likely generate inhibitory postsynaptic potential (IPSP)?

options.B: decreased membrane permeability to K<sup>+</sup> ion
options.C: increased membrane permeability to Ca<sup>2+</sup> ion
options.D: increased membrane permeability to Cl<sup>-</sup> ion
options.E: increased membrane permeability to Na<sup>+</sup> ion

18-19 HS2 Q20.explanation:
*Increased membrane permeability to Cl <sup>-</sup>*  
  
Note that for inhibitory postsynaptic potential, the effect should be hyperpolarization so that it is further away from the threshold.  

A. The Na<sup>+</sup>/K<sup>+</sup> ATPase is mainly responsible for maintaining the concentration gradient of Na<sup>+</sup> and K<sup>+</sup> across the cell membrane when the cell is *at rest*. Decreasing its activity won’t result in significant hyperpolarization.  
  
B. K<sup>+</sup> efflux will decrease, resulting in depolarization.  
  
C and E. Both result in the increase of influx of cations, resulting in depolarization. (EPSP generated)  
  
D. More Cl<sup>-</sup> leaves the cell resulting in hyperpolarization.

18-19 HS2 Q21.question: What will happen in neurons when voltage gated K<sup>+</sup> channels are blocked?

options.D: Resting membrane potential becomes more negative (hyperpolarization)
options.E: Repolarization phase of action potential is longer

18-19 HS2 Q21.explanation:

A. After-hyperpolarization will not occur.

C and D. Resting membrane potential is also unchanged as E<sub>K</sub> is not altered.  
  
E. The efflux of K<sup>+</sup> has a slower rate hence repolarization occur for a longer time. The refractory period is also longer.

19-20 HS2 Q34.question: In determining the equilibrium potential of a particular ion using the Nernst equation, which of the following would give rise to a higher absolute value (i.e., ignoring whether the value is positive or negative)?

options.B: Higher permeability of the cell membrane to the axon
options.C: Higher charge density of the ion
options.D: Higher number of charges carried by the ion (i.e. higher valency)
options.E: Larger concentration difference of the ion across the cell membrane

19-20 HS2 Q34.explanation:
*Larger concentration difference of the ion across the cell membrane*

Note that

$E = \frac{RT}{zF} \ln{\frac{[I]_o}{[I]_i}} = \frac{61.5}{z} \log{\frac{[I]_o}{[I]_i}} mV$

Where E = Equilibrium potential  
R = Universal gas constant (8.31 J K<sup>-1</sup> mol <sup>-1</sup>)  
T = Absolute temperature in K<sup>o</sup>
F = Faraday’s constant 9.65 x 10<sup>4</sup> C mol<sup>-1</sup>
Z = Valency of the ion (+ for cations, – for anions)
\[I\]<sub>o </sub> \= Ion concentration outside cell, \[I\]<sub>i </sub> \= Ion concentration inside cell

  
It can be easily observed that the higher concentration gradient of the ion will result in a higher |E<sub>ion</sub>|.  
If the question concerns E<sub>ion </sub> instead of |E<sub>ion</sub>|, then note that a higher concentration difference of the ion across the cell membrane will not necessarily give a higher E<sub>ion</sub>. But now only the magnitude is concerned, so E is the correct answer.

20-21 HS2 Q17.question: Which of the following is the best account of the occurrence of relative refractory period after the action potential period?

21-22 HS2 Q22.question:
A 50-year-old-man develops a medical condition in which his serum K<sup>+</sup> concentration increases to 6.1mM which is above normal (reference range: 3.5-5.1 mmol/L) and his serum Na<sup>+</sup> concentration decreases to below normal 130 mM (reference range: 135-145 mmol/L). Which of the following changes will correctly match the changes that occur on this man (considering that the intracellular Na<sup>+</sup> and K<sup>+</sup> concentrations are affected by the changes in the serum)  

| K<sup>+</sup> equilibrium potential | Na<sup>+</sup> equilibrium potential | Resting membrane potential |
| --- | --- | --- |

options.A:
| Less negative | Less positive | Less negative |
| --- | --- | --- |
options.B:
| Less negative | More positive | Less negative |
| --- | --- | --- |
options.C:
| Less negative | More positive | More positive |
| --- | --- | --- |
options.D:
| More positive | Less positive | Less negative |
| --- | --- | --- |
options.E:
| More positive | Less positive | More negative |
| --- | --- | --- |

21-22 HS2 Q22.explanation:
| K<sup>+</sup> equilibrium potential | Na<sup>+</sup> equilibrium potential | Resting membrane potential |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Less negative | Less positive | Less negative |
  
First consider each ion independently:

K<sup>+</sup>
 * The concentration gradient for K<sup>+</sup> across the cell membrane decreases, hence |E<sub>K</sub>| decreases.  
As E<sub>K</sub> is originally negative, hence E<sub>K</sub> now is less negative.

Na<sup>+</sup>
 * The concentration gradient for Na<sup>+</sup> across the cell membrane decreases, hence |E<sub>Na</sub>| decreases.  
As E<sub>Na</sub> is originally positive, hence E<sub>Na</sub> now is less positive.

Meanwhile, the resting membrane potential V<sub>M </sub> is a weighing of the average E<sub>ion</sub>.  
Originally V<sub>M</sub> is situated between E<sub>K</sub> and E<sub>Na</sub> and having a negative value.  
E<sub>K</sub> now is less negative -> Increases V<sub>M</sub>  
E<sub>Na</sub> now is less positive -> Decrease V<sub>M</sub>

As permeability of E<sub>K</sub> > E<sub>Na</sub>, influence on V<sub>M</sub> is greater for K<sup>+</sup>, hence overall, V<sub>M</sub> becomes less negative.

21-22 HS2 Q24.question: In determining the equilibrium potential for a particular ion, which of the following will give rise to a higher absolute value when calculated using the Nernst equation?

options.A: Higher charge density of the ion
options.B: Higher concentration difference of the ion across the cell membrane
options.C: Higher ionic radius of the ion
options.D: Higher number of charges carried by the ion (i.e. higher valency)
options.E: Higher permeability of the cell membrane to the ion

21-22 HS2 Q24.explanation:
*Higher concentration difference of the ion across the cell membrane*

Note that

$E = \frac{RT}{zF} \ln{\frac{[I]_o}{[I]_i}} = \frac{61.5}{z} \log{\frac{[I]_o}{[I]_i}} mV$

Where E = Equilibrium potential  
R = Universal gas constant (8.31 J K<sup>-1</sup> mol <sup>-1</sup>)  
T = Absolute temperature in K<sup>o</sup>
F = Faraday’s constant 9.65 x 10<sup>4</sup> C mol<sup>-1</sup>
Z = Valency of the ion (+ for cations, – for anions)
\[I\]<sub>o </sub> \= Ion concentration outside cell, \[I\]<sub>i </sub> \= Ion concentration inside cell

It can be easily observed that the higher concentration gradient of the ion will result in a higher |E<sub>ion</sub>|.  
If the question concerns E<sub>ion </sub> instead of |E<sub>ion</sub>|, then note that a higher concentration difference of the ion across the cell membrane will not necessarily give a higher E<sub>ion</sub>. But now only the magnitude is concerned, so B is the correct answer.

21-22 HS2 Q25.question: Which of the following would cause a rapid decrease in movement of K+ out of a neuronal cell?

options.E: Inhibiting the activity of Na<sup>+</sup>/K<sup>+</sup>\-ATPase pumps

21-22 HS2 Q25.explanation:
*Hyperpolarization of the membrane*  
  
Decrease in K<sup>+</sup> moving out of a cell is due to hyperpolarization.  
When hyperpolarization, then V<sub>M</sub> becomes more negative.  
By electrochemical force (positive value) = V<sub>M</sub> – E<sub>K</sub> (where V<sub>M</sub> is negative, E<sub>K</sub> is negative as well)  
Then V<sub>M</sub> more negative -> force on K<sup>+</sup> (efflux) decreases (less positive).

21-22 HS2 Q26.question: Which of the following charges would most likely result in the generation of IPSP?
21-22 HS2 Q26.explanation:
*Increased membrane permeability to Cl<sup>-</sup>*  
  
Note that for inhibitory postsynaptic potential, the effect should be hyperpolarization so that it is further away from the threshold.  
  
A. More Cl<sup>-</sup> will flow into the cell, resulting in hyperpolarization.  
  
B. The Na<sup>+</sup>/K<sup>+</sup> ATPase is mainly responsible for maintain the concentration gradient of Na<sup>+</sup> and K<sup>+</sup> across the cell membrane when the cell is *at rest*. Decreasing its activity won’t result in significant hyperpolarization.  
  
C. K<sup>+</sup> efflux will decrease, resulting in depolarization. (EPSP generated)  
  
D and E. Both result in the increase of influx of cations, resulting in depolarization. (EPSP generated)

21-22 HS2 Q27.question: Which of the following is common between graded potentials and action potentials? Both are:

options.D: Exhibit decrease in amplitude when spread away from their point of origin

21-22 HS2 Q27.explanation:
*Can give rise to depolarization*  
  
A. Associated with refractory periods *Incorrect*  
Only action potential is associated with refractory periods.  

B. Can be summated *Incorrect*  
Only graded potentials can be summated, not for action potential due to the refractory periods.  

C. Can give rise to depolarization *Correct*  
Both EPSP and action potential can give rise to depolarization.  

D. Exhibit decrease in amplitude when spread away from their point of origin *Incorrect*  
Only applicable to graded potentials.  

E. Originate from soma *Incorrect*  
Only applicable to graded potentials. Action potential originated from the spike initiation zone.

21-22 HS2 Q28.question: In the nervous system, which cells are similar to oligodendrocytes?
21-22 HS2 Q28.explanation:
*Schwann cells*  
  
One oligodendrocyte can myelinated multiple axons (in CNS), while each Schwann cell only myelinate one internodal segment (in PNS).

21-22 HS2 Q29.question: The parasympathetic and sympathetic divisions of ANS would considered as making up which component of a homeostatic control system

21-22 HS2 Q30.question: Which if the following muscle is under somatic motor control?

options.A: Arrector pili muscle attached to base of hair follicle

21-22 HS2 Q30.explanation:
*Limb muscle controlling muscle movement*  
  
A. Arrector pili muscle is associated with the ANS (sympathetic pathway). It will contract to trap a thicker layer of still air at the skin surface to reduce heat loss from body to surroundings by conduction. It contracts involuntarily, hence not somatic motor.  
  
C, D and E. These are all controlled by visceral motors and contracts/relax involuntarily.

22-23 HS2 Q1.question: In determining the equilibrium potential for a particular ion, which of the following will give rise to a higher absolute value when calculated using the Nernst equation?

options.A: Higher charge density of the ion
options.B: Higher concentration difference of the ion across the cell membrane
options.C: Higher ionic radius of the ion
options.D: Higher number of charges carried by the ion (i.e. higher valency)
options.E: Higher permeability of the cell membrane to the ion

22-23 HS2 Q1.explanation:
*Higher concentration difference of the ion across the cell membrane*

Note that

$E = \frac{RT}{zF} \ln{\frac{[I]_o}{[I]_i}} = \frac{61.5}{z} \log{\frac{[I]_o}{[I]_i}} mV$

Where E = Equilibrium potential  
R = Universal gas constant (8.31 J K<sup>-1</sup> mol <sup>-1</sup>)  
T = Absolute temperature in K<sup>o</sup>
F = Faraday’s constant 9.65 x 10<sup>4</sup> C mol<sup>-1</sup>
Z = Valency of the ion (+ for cations, – for anions)
\[I\]<sub>o </sub> \= Ion concentration outside cell, \[I\]<sub>i </sub> \= Ion concentration inside cell

It can be easily observed that the higher concentration gradient of the ion will result in a higher |E<sub>ion</sub>|.  
If the question concerns E<sub>ion </sub> instead of |E<sub>ion</sub>|, then note that a higher concentration difference of the ion across the cell membrane will not necessarily give a higher E<sub>ion</sub>. But now only the magnitude is concerned, so B is the correct answer.

22-23 HS2 Q3.question: Which regions of the myelin sheath contains the largest density of voltage gated ion channels?
22-23 HS2 Q3.explanation:
*Node of Ranvier*  
  
It should be noted that the highest density of voltage-gated ion channels are not found in the axon hillock despite the fact that it is involved in the generation of action potential. Moreover, it isn’t 'a region of the myelin sheath'.

22-23 HS2 Q4.question: Which of the following changes will result in the generation of IPSPs
22-23 HS2 Q4.explanation:
*Deceased membrane permeability to Ca<sup>2+</sup>*

  
Note that for inhibitory postsynaptic potential, the effect should be hyperpolarization so that it is further away from the threshold.  
  
A. The Na<sup>+</sup>/K<sup>+</sup> ATPase is mainly responsible for maintain the concentration gradient of Na<sup>+</sup> and K<sup>+</sup> across the cell membrane when the cell is *at rest*. Decreasing its activity won’t result in significant hyperpolarization.  
  
B. Less Cl<sup>-</sup> will flow into the cell, resulting in depolarization. (EPSP generated)  
  
C. Na<sup>+</sup> influx will increase, resulting in depolarization. (EPSP generated)  
  
D. K<sup>+</sup> efflux will decrease, resulting in depolarization. (EPSP generated)  
  
E. Ca<sup>2+</sup> influx will decrease, resulting in hyperpolarization.

22-23 HS2 Q5.question:
| Unknown ion | Equilibrium potentials (in mV) |
| ----- | ----- |
| P (Cation) | +120 |
| Q (Cation) | +60 |
| R (Cation) | -25 |
| S (Anion) | -75 |
| T (Anion) | -90 |

Given that the resting membrane potential is -70 mV.  
Which ion is exerted by the highest electrochemical driving force?
22-23 HS2 Q5.explanation:
*P*  
  
The data is being tabulated:

| Unknown ion | Electrochemical driving force (in mV) |
| ----- | ----- |
| P (Cation) | -190 |
| Q (Cation) | -130 |
| R (Cation) | -45 |
| S (Anion) | +5 |
| T (Anion) | +20 |

Note that electrochemical driving force = V<sub>M</sub> - E<sub>ion</sub>  
  
For electrochemical driving force, the magnitude is being concerned. Hence P experienced the greatest electrochemical driving force.

22-23 HS2 Q6.question:
The following diagram shows the action potential recorded from a nerve fiber? At which of the following labelled points would there be the smallest driving force on K<sup>+</sup>?

![](img/22-23_HS2_Q6_1754584449722.jpeg)
22-23 HS2 Q6.explanation:
*5*  
  
Electrochemical driving force = V<sub>M</sub> - E<sub>ion</sub>  
As E<sub>K</sub> approximately equals to -90mV, point 5 is the position resulting in closest V<sub>M</sub> to E<sub>K</sub>.  
(i.e. smallest electrochemical driving force)

22-23 HS2 Q7.question: Which of the following best accounts for the absolute refractory period after the action potential.

options.C: Increase in activity of Na/K ATPase

22-23 HS2 Q7.explanation:
*Inactivation of voltage-gated Na*<sup>+</sup> *channels*

  
When voltage-gated Na<sup>+</sup> channels are opened, membrane permeability to sodium ions greatly increase, eventually resulting in depolarization of the membrane, which also causes the inactivation of the voltage-gated Na<sup>+</sup> channels.  
Due to a very high proportion of Na<sup>+</sup> channels being inactivated, it is impossible for another upshoot/ depolarization, i.e. impossible to generate another action potential, during the absolute refractory period.  
  
A. The absolute refractory period is not related to K<sup>+</sup>.  
  
B. It is impossible to generate another action potential during the absolute refractory period.  
Second action potential is elected provided that a higher-than-normal stimulus is triggered occurs during the relative refractory period. Hence there no exists threshold potential during the absolute refractory period.  
  
C. Irrelevant.

22-23 HS2 Q9.question: What is the location of cell bodies of somatic motor neurons in the spinal cord?

options.B: Grey matter of the dorsal horn

23-24 HS2 Q1.question: Identify which of the following is true.

options.A: The electrical and chemical gradients of Ca<sup>2+</sup> are in opposite directions.
options.B: The electrical and chemical gradients of K<sup>+</sup> are in the same directions.
options.C: The electrical and chemical gradients of Cl<sup>-</sup> are in the same directions.
options.D: The electrical and chemical gradients of Na<sup>+</sup> are the same directions.
options.E: The electrical gradients of Na<sup>+</sup> and K<sup>+</sup> are in opposite directions.

23-24 HS2 Q1.explanation:
*The electrical and chemical gradients of Na*<sup>+</sup> *are the same directions.*  
  
Note that the gradient produces a force, which has the same direction as the gradient.

|  | Electrical force | Chemical force | Electrical and chemical force |
| --- | ----- | ------ | ----- |
| Ca<sup>2+</sup> | Pointing inside the cell | Pointing inside the cell | Same direction |
| Na<sup>+</sup> | Pointing inside the cell | Pointing inside the cell | Same direction |
| K<sup>+</sup> | Pointing inside the cell | Pointing outside the cell | Opposite direction |
| Cl<sup>-</sup> | Pointing outside the cell | Pointing inside the cell | Opposite direction |

23-24 HS2 Q2.question: Which of the following would most likely result in a decreased amplitude of action potential in a typical neuron?

options.B: Triggering an action potential in relative refractory period
options.C: Reduced permeability of membrane to K<sup>+</sup>

23-24 HS2 Q2.explanation:
*Triggering an action potential in relative refractory period*  
  
A. Amplitude is unchanged.  
  
B. Some voltage-gated Na<sup>+</sup> channels are still inactivated, meaning that less Na<sup>+</sup> will go into the cell during the relative refractory period. As a result, the amplitude of action potential decreases because the effect of depolarization is less.  
  
C. This will not decrease the amplitude of action potential. The depolarization period has nothing to do with K<sup>+</sup>.  
  
D and E. These will result in greater depolarization effect, i.e. increased amplitude of action potential.

23-24 HS2 Q3.question: Which of the following would most likely result from a blockade of K<sup>+ </sup> channels?
23-24 HS2 Q3.explanation:
*Prolonged repolarization*  
  
Note that a blockade of K<sup>+</sup> channels reduces permeability of K<sup>+</sup>.  
Hence there will be two major effects:  
1. Repolarization will take a longer time due to slower rate of repolarization.  
2. Barely can hyperpolarization be seen due to lower permeability of K<sup>+</sup>.

23-24 HS2 Q4.question: Which of the following glial cells supplies the myelin sheath of neurons?
23-24 HS2 Q4.explanation:
**E is also accepted**

*Oligodendrocytes* or *Schwann cells*  
  
Oligodendrocytes for CNS and Schwann cells for PNS.

23-24 HS2 Q5.question: Which is true about PNS

options.A: All spinal nerves contain both motor and sensory neurons

23-24 HS2 Q5.explanation:
*All spinal nerves contain both motor and sensory neurons*

Spinal nerves are mixed nerves.

23-24 HS2 MID-TERM Q21.question: From which region of the central nervous system do the cranial nerves arise from?

23-24 HS2 MID-TERM Q22.question: Where are voltage-gated Ca<sup>2+</sup> channels expressed?
23-24 HS2 MID-TERM Q22.explanation:
*Axon terminal*  
  
At the axon terminal, when there is depolarizing current arriving, then this will trigger the opening of the voltage-gated calcium channels. This results in the influx of Ca<sup>2+</sup> which triggers the fusion of synaptic vesicles (with neurotransmitters) with presynaptic membrane so that the neurotransmitters can be released to the synapse and bind to the receptors on the postsynaptic density of the postsynaptic membrane of the next soma/dendrite of neuron/effector.

12-13 HS1 Q17.question: Which of the following can increase evaporative heat loss from the skin surface?

options.A: Contraction of arrector pili muscle of hair follicle.
options.B: Decreased air flow over the skin surface.

12-13 HS1 Q17.explanation:
*Increased skin temperature.*

  
A. This will trap more still air at the skin surface, resulting in a reduction in convective heat loss.  
  
B. This will reduce in reduced heat loss via convection and evaporation.  
  
C. This decreases the water vapour pressure gradient between the skin surface and the ambient air.  
As a result, evaporative heat loss from skin surface decreases.  
  
D. This increases the rate of evaporation as the water molecules have a higher kinetic energy.  
Moreover, increased skin temperature will result in increased rate and amount of sweating, hence result in higher rate of evaporation of sweat, hence increase evaporative heat loss from skin surface.  
  
E. This reduces heat loss via radiation (shiny silvery surface is poor radiator) and convection (limits air flow over body surface).

12-13 HS1 Q18.question: Which of the following statement is INAPPROPRIATE for the thermoregulatory change during intense exercise?

options.C: Splash water on the exposure area.

12-13 HS1 Q18.explanation:
*Contraction of arrector pili muscle.*

  
During intense exercise, skeletal muscles contract more vigorously, resulting in huge increase in heat production. Both body core and peripheral temperature increases, stimulating the central and peripheral/ cutaneous thermoreceptors respectively (warm receptors to be specific).  
Note that there are more warm receptors in body core than body surface.  
They send more signals to the preoptic area of hypothalamus/hypothalamic thermoregulatory center, which detects an increase in body temperature, thus send more signals to the anterior nuclei of hypothalamus, thus resulting in actions for heat dissipation/less heat generation. The sympathetic cholinergic neurons are stimulated for this purpose.  
  
A. This will result in less heat dissipation at body surface via convection. Body temperature will further increases.  
  
C. This increases evaporative heat loss from body surface. Conductive heat loss also enhanced. 
  
D. This increases heat loss via convection (mainly). This is because the action results in an increased airflow over the body. Hence evaporative heat loss will also increase.

12-13 HS1 Q19.question: Why mercury in glass thermometer is not used nowadays?

options.A: The thin thread is hard to read.
options.B: Mercury is too slow in response to give an accurate reading.
options.C: Mercury has a high specific heat capacity.
options.D: Mercury is toxic to us when the thermometer is accidentally broken.
options.E: Mercury in glass thermometer needs calibration.

12-13 HS1 Q19.explanation: *Mercury is toxic to us when the thermometer is accidentally broken.*

12-13 HS1 Q20.question: Which of the following heat transfer is detected when using the tympanic membrane thermometer to measure the body temperature?
12-13 HS1 Q20.explanation:
*Radiation*  
  
In fact, the full name of the thermometer is called infrared tympanic membrane thermometer. It measures the infrared emitted from the tympanic membrane which is supplied by the anterior tympanic artery.

13-14 HS1 Q48.explanation:
*Radiation*  
  
In fact, the full name of the thermometer is called infrared tympanic membrane thermometer. It measures the infrared emitted from the tympanic membrane which is supplied by the anterior tympanic artery.

13-14 HS1 Q50.question: Which of the following would result in increased evaporative heat loss from the skin surface?

options.A: Contraction of arrector pili muscle in hair follicles
options.C: Increased air flow on skin surface

13-14 HS1 Q50.explanation:
*Increased air flow on skin surface*  
  
A. This results in decreased conductive heat loss but has nothing to do with evaporative heat loss.  
  
B. This decreases the water vapour pressure gradient between ambient air and the skin surface hence reduces evaporative heat loss from the skin surface.  
  
C. This will carry the water vapour in ambient air (evaporated from the skin surface) away from body more quickly, thus maintaining steep gradient of water vapour pressure between skin surface and ambient air.  
Hence evaporative heat loss from skin surface increases.  
  
D. This will reduce the evaporative heat loss from skin surface as water molecules has less kinetic energy.  
Also, this will decrease rate and amount of sweating, hence reduces water vapour pressure at skin surface. This also reduces evaporative heat loss from skin surface.

13-14 HS1 Q54.question: What is the direct effect of pyrogens in development of a fever?

options.B: reduce sweat production by sweat gland
options.C: increase production of prostaglandin in hypothalamus
options.D: increase thyroxine produced by thyroid gland
options.E: increase heat production by muscle shivering

13-14 HS1 Q54.explanation:
*Increase production of prostaglandin in hypothalamus* Pyrogens are chemical substances causing fever, usually proteins or toxins. Note that there are two types of pyrogens, exogenous and endogenous pyrogens. Below are their properties: | Exogenous pyrogens | Endogenous pyrogens | | ----- | ----- | | Originating outside the body | Originating inside the body | | Examples are bacterial endotoxin (lipopolysaccharides LPS in cell wall of gram-negative bacteria), foreign antigens and other products from microorganisms. | Examples include pyrogenic cytokines produced by our immune system (IL-1, IL-6, TNF-α). | | - Induce the production of endogenous pyrogens (such as pyrogenic cytokines); or
- act on toll-like receptors (TLR) on the organ vasculosum lamina terminalis (OVLT) to stimulate the production of prostaglandin E2 (PGE2). | They enter the perivascular space of the vascular network, i.e. the OVLT, supplying the thermoregulatory center in anterior hypothalamus via fenestrated capillary wall to stimulate the endothelial production of PGE2. | PGE2 (from endothelial production at the anterior hypothalamus) diffuse into adjacent preoptic area to raise the temperature set point. An error signal will be produced, stimulating the posterior hypothalamus (heat gain center) to increase heat production and reduce heat dissipation so that the body temperature can rise to the new set point. The antipyretic effects of paracetamol/acetaminophen is due to the inhibition of PGE2 synthesis. The constriction of blood vessel (option A), reduce sweat production (option B) and increase shivering thermogenesis (option E) are all the results of the increase in temperature set point. Note that typically, thyroxine production by thyroid gland won’t increase significantly in a fever (option C).

14-15 HS1 Q13.question: On China's national day, a maritime accident occurred in Hong Kong off Lamma Island. Some people jumped off the boat into the water. When they are rescued, which of the following is the major means of heat loss to surroundings?
14-15 HS1 Q13.explanation:
*Evaporation*  
  
In water, main source of heat loss is by convection. (assuming that the sea water is cold)  
When they are just rescued note that they are <u>above water surface</u>, and that evaporation becomes the main source of heat loss as the water vapour pressure gradient between ambient air and skin surface is very high. Convection in the meantime becomes less significant.  
In fact, this is also the reason why we feel cold when getting out of a swimming pool – due to evaporative heat loss.  
**Most sources said that E should be the best option. Please decide which option is the best.**

14-15 HS1 Q14.question: On a sunny day, when a subject move from standing directly under the sun to a place under the shade, which of the following forms of heat transfer between the body and the environment would be the most affected?
14-15 HS1 Q14.explanation:
*Radiation*  
  
The heat gain by radiation (from the sun) would be significantly reduced.

14-15 HS1 Q15.question: Which processes of heat transfer are used by a tympanic membrane thermometer to measure body temperature?
14-15 HS1 Q15.explanation:
*Radiation*  
  
In fact, the full name of the thermometer is called infrared tympanic membrane thermometer. It measures the infrared emitted from the tympanic membrane which is supplied by the anterior tympanic artery.

14-15 HS1 Q16.question: Which of the following structures is most likely to have the highest temperature when the subject is comfortably dressed, standing upright at rest under shade, in a still (windless) environment at 20 degree Celsius?

options.E: All of the above is the same

14-15 HS1 Q16.explanation:
*Forehead*  
  
Note that the body temperature is the lowest at body extremities (i.e. periphery of the body) such as the toe and finger.

14-15 HS1 Q17.question: Which of the following choices is most likely to cause an increase in evaporative loss from skin surface?

options.D: Relaxation of arrector pili muscles of hair follicles

14-15 HS1 Q17.explanation:
*Decrease in air humidity*  
  
This can increase the water vapour pressure gradient between the skin surface and the ambient air thus increase evaporative heat loss from skin surface.  
  
A. This increase heat loss by conduction, because the adipose tissue layer (which is good heat insulator) is thinner.  
  
C. This increase conductive and radiative heat loss, but decreases evaporative heat loss.  
  
D. This increases conductive heat loss because the layer of still air trapped in skin surface is thinner.  
  
E. This increases blood flow to the skin surface hence increases heat loss mainly by conduction and radiation but not evaporation nor convection.

14-15 HS1 Q18.question: At the onset of fever,

options.D: Temperature sensation of central thermoreceptor is blocked by pyrogen

14-15 HS1 Q18.explanation:
*Shivering is activated*  
  
Fever is due to the endothelial production of PGE<sub>2</sub> at the anterior hypothalamus due to stimulated by endogenous/exogenous pyrogens via different pathways. PGE<sub>2</sub> diffuses to adjacent preoptic area of hypothalamus hence increases the temperature set point, resulting in the generation of error signal that stimulates the posterior nucleus of hypothalamus to initiate responses to reduce heat dissipation and increase heat generation.  
  
A. Shivering can effectively increase thermogenesis.  
  
B. This will increase heat loss to surroundings from the body.  
  
C. This increases evaporative heat loss from skin surface.  
  
D. This is not the main effect of pyrogens, which are substances inducing the development of fever.  
  
E. Thyroxine is mainly responsible for maintaining basal metabolic rate and won’t significantly  
increase during onset of fever.

15-16 HS1 Q16.question: Which of the following surfaces would best reflect radiant heat?
15-16 HS1 Q16.explanation:
*Shiny silvery surface*  
  
Meanwhile dull black surface (option A) is the best absorber for radiant heat.

15-16 HS1 Q17.question: Which of the following represents the major means of heat transfer between the body core and body shell?
15-16 HS1 Q17.explanation:
*Convection*  
  
Achieved through muscle blood flow and skin blood flow.  
Note that it is regulated by cutaneous blood flow.  
When cutaneous blood vessels dilate then more blood get closer to skin surface, carrying more heat from body core to the skin.  
Meanwhile if cutaneous blood vessels constrict then more blood travels through shunt vessels/ arteriovenous anastomoses, with less blood flowing to skin surface, less heat from the body core transferred to the body shell.

15-16 HS1 Q19.question: Which is not an appropriate thermoregulatory response when in dehydration and after prolonged intense exercise?

options.D: Reduced blood flow to cutaneous arteriovenous anastomoses

15-16 HS1 Q19.explanation:
*Reduced sweating*  
  
A. Drink cold water can actively lower the body core temperature and alleviate dehydration.  
  
B. This increases heat loss by conduction and evaporation from skin surface.  
  
C. It occurs as a result of dehydration when the body conserves water, but it impairs the body’s ability to cool itself by evaporation.  
  
D. This can increase cutaneous blood flow, more heat is dissipated at skin surface by radiation and conduction.  
  
E. This enhances air circulation (heat loss by convection) and evaporative cooling.

15-16 HS1 Q20.question:
Person drinks hot tea very quickly, then sweats after. What is the correct pathway for homeostatic control?

1. Core sensory neuron

2. Peripheral sensory neuron

3. Sweat gland

4. Motor neuron

5. Thermoregulatory centre in brain stem

6. Thermoregulatory centre in hypothalamus
15-16 HS1 Q20.explanation: *Core sensory neuron -> Thermoregulatory center in hypothalamus -> Motor neuron -> Sweat gland*

16-17 HS1 Q43.question: Sweating represents an important means of heat loss from our body because:

options.A: Flow of sweat carried heat from the body core to the body shell by convection
options.B: Water evaporates quickly due to its low boiling point
options.C: Water has high latent heat of fusion
options.D: Water has high latent heat of vaporization
options.E: Water has high specific heat capacity

16-17 HS1 Q43.explanation:
*Water has high latent heat of vaporization*  
  
By E = ml<sub>v</sub>, for high l<sub>v</sub> then E loss is significant.

16-17 HS1 Q44.question: Temperature measurement taken at which of the following site would best represent the body core temperature?
16-17 HS1 Q44.explanation:
*Rectum*  
  
This method is usually used in measuring the body core temperature for babies.

16-17 HS1 Q45.question: A naked individual is sitting on a metal chair at a room with still air, ambient temperature of 21℃ and 90% humidity, what are major ways of heat loss?
16-17 HS1 Q45.explanation:
*Conduction and radiation*  
  
Ambient temperature of 21℃ -> High rate of heat loss by radiation and conduction  
Radiation is more significant than conduction  
90% humidity -> Low water vapour pressure gradient between skin surface and ambient air -> Evaporative heat loss is not significant  
Still air -> Heat loss by convection is not significant

16-17 HS1 Q46.question: In case that a patient in severe burn with significant percentage of body surface area affected. Which of the followings would best describe the cause of defect in thermoregulation?

options.A: Damage of warm receptor in skin
options.B: Inability to produce sweat by sweat gland
options.D: Raise the set point of hypothalamic thermoregulatory centre
options.E: Reduced blood flow to skin surface

16-17 HS1 Q46.explanation:
*Reduced blood flow to skin surface*  
  
A. There are still many warm receptors in the body core, particularly at the hypothalamus.  
They are central thermoreceptors, located at the hypothalamus, abdominal viscera, in/around spinal cord and great veins to sense core temperature.  
  
B. This is true, but evaporation isn’t the main heat loss pathway.  
  
C. The neuronal pathways are mostly preserved.  
  
D. The preoptic area of hypothalamus is not affected.  
  
E. Due to damage in blood vessels, this significantly impairs the skin’s ability to participate in heat exchange with the environment, which is critical for both heat dissipation (in hot environments) and heat conservation (in cold environments). As a result, there are defects in thermoregulation.

17-18 HS1 Q19.question: Measurement of which of the following sites would give the shell body temperature closest to core body temperature?
17-18 HS1 Q19.explanation:
*Armpit*  
  
Measurement at the tympanic membrane gives the core body temperature/intracranial temperature instead of the shell body temperature.

17-18 HS1 Q20.question: Which of the following would result in increased evaporative heat loss from the skin surface?

options.A: Contraction of arrector pili muscle in hair follicles
options.C: Increased air flow on skin surface

17-18 HS1 Q20.explanation:
*Increased air flow on skin surface*  
  
This will carry the water vapour in ambient air (evaporated from the skin surface) away from body more quickly, thus maintaining steep gradient of water vapour pressure between skin surface and ambient air.  
Hence evaporative heat loss from skin surface increases.

17-18 HS1 Q21.question: A naked individual is sitting on a metal chair at a room with still air, ambient temperature of 21℃ and 90% humidity, what are major ways of heat loss?
17-18 HS1 Q21.explanation:
*Conduction and radiation*  
  
Ambient temperature of 21℃ -> High rate of heat loss by radiation and conduction  
Metal chair (good conductor of heat) -> High rate of heat loss by conduction  
90% humidity -> Low water vapour pressure gradient between skin surface and ambient air -> Evaporative heat loss is not significant  
Still air -> Heat loss by convection is not significant

17-18 HS1 Q22.question: In case that a patient in severe burn with significant percentage of body surface area affected. Which of the followings would best describe the cause of defect in thermoregulation?

options.A: Damage of warm receptors in skin
options.B: Inability to produce sweat by sweat gland
options.D: Raise the set point of hypothalamic thermoregulatory centre
options.E: Reduced blood flow to skin surface

17-18 HS1 Q22.explanation:
*Reduced blood flow to skin surface*  
  
A. There are still many warm receptors in the body core, particularly at the hypothalamus.  
They are central thermoreceptors, located at the hypothalamus, abdominal viscera, in/around spinal cord and great veins to sense core temperature.  
  
B. This is true, but evaporation isn’t the main heat loss pathway.  
  
C. The neuronal pathways are mostly preserved.  
  
D. The preoptic area of hypothalamus is not affected.  
  
E. Due to damage in blood vessels, this significantly impairs the skin’s ability to participate in heat exchange with the environment, which is critical for both heat dissipation (in hot environments) and heat conservation (in cold environments). As a result, there are defects in thermoregulation.

17-18 HS1 Q23.question: Which of following happens during the onset of fever?

options.C: Blood flow to the skin is reduced.

17-18 HS1 Q23.explanation:
*Blood flow to the skin is reduced*  
  
Fever is due to the endothelial production of PGE<sub>2</sub> at the anterior hypothalamus due to stimulated by endogenous/exogenous pyrogens via different pathways.  
PGE<sub>2</sub> diffuses to adjacent preoptic area of hypothalamus hence increases the temperature set point, resulting in the generation of error signal that stimulates the posterior nuclei of hypothalamus to initiate responses to reduce heat dissipation and increase heat generation.  
  
A. Behavioral responses such as wearing more clothes are stimulated.  
  
B. The hypothalamus heat gain center (i.e. the posterior nuclei) is activated.  
  
C. Blood flow to skin is reduced due to vasoconstriction. This helps in heat conservation.  
  
D. Shivering thermogenesis is activated to increase heat production in body.  
  
E. Sweating is decreased to reduce heat loss via evaporation.

18-19 HS2 Q32.question: At the cross-border check point, thermal imaging relies on which form of heat transfer for detecting subjects who have developed fever?
18-19 HS2 Q32.explanation:
*Radiation*  
  
Through infrared thermography/thermal imaging using an infrared camera.

19-20 HS2 Q12.question: Which of the following would give the shell body temperature that is closest to the core body temperature?

19-20 HS2 Q16.question: Which of the following means of heat transfer is employed in the use of tympanic membrane thermometer for measuring our body temperature?
19-20 HS2 Q16.explanation:
*Radiation*  
  
In fact, the full name of the thermometer is called infrared tympanic membrane thermometer. It measures the infrared emitted from the tympanic membrane which is supplied by the anterior tympanic artery.

19-20 HS2 Q36.question: Which of the following represents the direct effect of pyrogens in inducing the development of fever?

options.A: Stimulate prostaglandin production in the hypothalamus
options.B: Induce vasoconstriction of skin blood vessels
options.C: Induce shivering thermogenesis of skeletal muscles
options.D: Reduce sweat production by sweat glands
options.E: Stimulate thyroid hormone secretion to raise basal metabolic rate

19-20 HS2 Q36.explanation:
*Stimulate prostaglandin production in the hypothalamus*  
  
Fever is due to the endothelial production of PGE<sub>2</sub> at the anterior hypothalamus due to stimulated by endogenous/exogenous pyrogens via different pathways.  
PGE<sub>2</sub> diffuses to adjacent preoptic area of hypothalamus hence increases the temperature set point, resulting in the generation of error signal that stimulates the posterior nuclei of hypothalamus to initiate responses to reduce heat dissipation and increase heat generation.
