These include actions like vasoconstriction (option B), increased shivering thermogenesis (option C) and reduction in sweat production (option D).

20-21 HS2 Q24.question: Why is mercury-in-glass thermometer not used nowadays?

options.A: Difficult to obtain an accurate reading due to the thin thread
options.C: High specific heat capacity of mercury
options.E: Mercury and mercury vapour are neurotoxic

20-21 HS2 Q26.question: Which of the following will reduce evaporative heat loss?
20-21 HS2 Q26.explanation:
*Higher air humidity*  
  
This decreases the gradient of water vapour pressure between skin surface and the ambient air hence reduce evaporative heat loss from the skin surface.

20-21 HS2 Q27.question: At the rising phase of fever:

options.A: Temperature of skin surface is below normal
options.C: Heat loss center at anterior nucleus is excited

20-21 HS2 Q27.explanation:
*Temperature of skin surface is below normal*  
  
A. Note that the body will prioritize to keep the internal core warm.  
Furthermore, vasoconstriction occurs during fever, resulting in less cutaneous blood flow, hence the skin temperature becomes lower than normal.  
  
B. Behavioural responses such as wearing more clothes are typically enhanced during the rising phase of fever.  
  
C. Heat loss center is inhibited. The heat gain center at posterior nucleus is excited.  
  
D. Muscle blood flow decreases (due to vasoconstriction).  
  
E. Less sweat is secreted by sweat glands.

20-21 HS2 Q28.question: After invasion of COVID-19 virus into the body, which of the following causes the development of fever?

options.A: Cytokine produced by immune cells increase pyrogen level
options.B: Increased blood flow caused by vasculitis
options.C: Metabolic rate increase due to thyroxine secretion
options.D: Metabolic rate increase due to stress hormone adrenaline
options.E: Prostaglandin increase due to inflammatory response

20-21 HS2 Q28.explanation:
*Prostaglandin increase due to inflammatory response*  
  
COVID-19 has foreign antigens on the virus surface, considered as exogenous pyrogens.  
They will stimulate the immune cells (such as neutrophils and macrophages) to produce pyrogenic cytokines/proinflammatory mediators/endogenous pyrogens such as interleukin-1, interleukin-6 and tumour necrosis factor. This is the inflammatory response.  
These cytokines are endogenous pyrogens, they will enter the OVLT (organ vasculosum lamina terminalis) then supply the anterior hypothalamus through fenestrated capillary wall to stimulate the endothelial production of PGE<sub>2</sub> which diffuse into adjacent preoptic area to raise the temperature set point, causing fever.  
In other words, the cytokines (produced due to inflammatory responses by the immune system) will increase the production of prostaglandin, ultimately resulting in fever.  
Note that option A (increasing pyrogen level) only results in increased production of PGE<sub>2</sub> which is the direct cause of development of fever.

21-22 HS2 Q31.question: A 24-year-old man goes hiking in the Mojave Desert which is also known as the Dead Valley. The environmental temperature is 24<sup>o</sup>C and the relative humidity of ambient air is at 20%. Which of the following would represent his major mechanism of heat loss for body temperature control?
21-22 HS2 Q31.explanation:
*Evaporation*  
  
At such a low humidity (20%), the water vapour pressure gradient between the ambient air and skin surface is very high, making heat loss by evaporation very efficient.  
Meanwhile, note that the ambient air is only 24<sup>o</sup>C. This makes heat loss by radiation is not really very efficient due to only normal difference of temperature between the body and the ambient air.  
As a result, evaporation would be the major mechanism of heat loss.

21-22 HS2 Q32.question: A 22-year-old man went on a camping trip. He underestimated the cool evening temperatures, so he wrapped himself in a thin sheet of polyester film with a reflective surface (a foil reflective blanket). Which of the following mechanisms of heat transfer would be most affected reducing his heat loss?
21-22 HS2 Q32.explanation:
*Radiation*  
  
Objects with reflective surfaces are poor radiators hence reduce heat loss by radiation significantly.  
Although this act can also cut off the air flow over the body surface (i.e. reduce heat loss by convection), the question didn’t state whether the environment is windy or not, but just only ‘a cool evening’. In case the current environment is not very windy (i.e. still air) with cool temperatures, then heat loss by convection, no matter with or without the blanket, won’t be very significant anyway.

21-22 HS2 Q33.question: Which of the following would give the shell body temperature that is least influenced by the ambient air temperature?

21-22 HS2 Q34.question: In a thermoregulatory response, which of the following would be responsible for stimulating an increase in sweat gland?
21-22 HS2 Q34.explanation:
*Sympathetic cholinergic nerves*  
  
Note that the sympathetic cholinergic nerves are responsible for heat dissipation/reduction in heat production, for instance, stimulating an increase in sweat production (both in rate and amount) by stimulating the sweat gland to increase heat loss from skin surface by evaporation.  
Sympathetic adrenergic nerves are responsible for heat conservation/generation, for instance, vasoconstriction and piloerection.  
Note that shivering thermogenesis (i.e. shivering of skeletal muscles) is due to somatic motor neurons but not sympathetic adrenergic neurons.

21-22 HS2 Q35.question: At the cross border checkpoint, thermal imaging relies on which form of heat transfer for detecting subjects that developed fever?
21-22 HS2 Q35.explanation:
*Radiation*  
  
Through infrared thermography/thermal imaging using an infrared camera. (not infrared thermometer)

22-23 HS2 Q10.question: Which of the following are ways of heat transfer within the body?
22-23 HS2 Q10.explanation:
*Convection*  
  
Note that convection is the main way for heat to be transferred from the body core to skin surface.  
Mainly include skin blood flow and muscle blood flow.  
Regulated by cutaneous blood flow.  
When cutaneous blood vessels dilate then more blood get closer to skin surface, carrying more heat from body core to the skin.  
Meanwhile if cutaneous blood vessels constrict then more blood travels through shunt vessels/ arteriovenous anastomoses, with less blood flowing to skin surface, less heat from the body core transferred to the body shell.

22-23 HS2 Q11.question: What is the most likely to increase the evaporative heat loss of the body?
22-23 HS2 Q11.explanation:
*Decreased humidity*  
  
Decreased humidity will increase the gradient of water vapour pressure between the skin surface and the ambient air thus increase rate of evaporation of sweat from the skin surface hence increase evaporative heat loss of the body.

22-23 HS2 Q13.question: Which processes of heat transfer are used by a tympanic membrane thermometer to measure body temperature?
22-23 HS2 Q13.explanation:
*Radiation*  
  
In fact, the full name of the thermometer is called infrared tympanic membrane thermometer. It measures the infrared emitted from the tympanic membrane which is supplied by the anterior tympanic artery.

23-24 HS2 MID-TERM Q10.question: Which of the following means of heat loss will be affected most when the subject is covered in a thin sheet of polyester film with a reflective surface (Mylar), also known as emergency blanket or space blanket?
23-24 HS2 MID-TERM Q10.explanation:
*Convection and radiation*  
  
Convection: Note that the sheet will cut off air flow over the body surface, hence less heat loss by convection.  
Radiation: The reflective surface (silvery) is a poor radiator hence reduce heat loss from body by radiation.

23-24 HS2 MID-TERM Q11.question: In a thermoregulatory response, which of the following is responsible for the vasodilation of the cutaneous blood vessel?
23-24 HS2 MID-TERM Q11.explanation:
*Sympathetic cholinergic nerves*  
  
Note that the sympathetic cholinergic nerves are responsible for heat dissipation/reduction in heat production, for instance, vasodilation of cutaneous blood vessel to increase flow of blood to skin surface to facilitate increased heat dissipation from body via conduction and radiation.  
Sympathetic adrenergic nerves are responsible for heat conservation/generation, for instance, vasoconstriction and piloerection.  
Note that shivering thermogenesis (i.e. shivering of skeletal muscles) is due to somatic motor neurons but not sympathetic adrenergic neurons.

23-24 HS2 MID-TERM Q12.question: Fever refers to the abnormal rise in temperature owing to pathological conditions. Which of the followings produced in hypothalamus is responsible for increasing the set point of thermoregulation?
23-24 HS2 MID-TERM Q12.explanation:
*Prostaglandin E<sub>2</sub>*

Note that pyrogens will stimulate the endothelial production/synthesis of prostaglandin E<sub>2</sub> at anterior hypothalamus, PGE<sub>2</sub> then diffuse into adjacent preoptic area (i.e. the hypothalamic thermoregulatory center) and increases its set point at the onset of fever.  
  
B: Exogenous pyrogens refer to pyrogens (which are chemical substances able to induce fever in body) originated from outside the body.  
Example include bacterial endotoxin (option D) (e.g. lipopolysaccharides, LPS in cell wall of  
gram-negative bacteria), foreign antigens as well as other substances products from microorganisms.  
Note that they will either stimulate the immune system to synthesis endogenous pyrogens  
(proinflammatory mediators) such as interleukin-1 (Option E), interleukin-6 and tumour necrosis factor (option C); or engage with specific toll-like receptors (TLR) on the organ vasculosum lamina terminalis (OVLT) to produce PGE<sub>2</sub> (option A).

23-24 HS2 MID-TERM Q25.question: In Hong Kong, The Standard Chartered Hong Kong Marathon is usually organized in springtime. Which of the following means of heat transfer is the most adversely affected when the air humidity is high?
23-24 HS2 MID-TERM Q25.explanation:
*Evaporation*  
  
When the air humidity is high, note that the gradient of water vapour pressure between skin surface and ambient air decreases dramatically, hence resulting in very lower rate of evaporation of sweat from skin surface, leading to much lower rate of evaporative heat loss from skin surface.  
  
Rate of heat gain/loss by conduction, convection or radiation is not affected greatly by humidity.

13-14 HS1 Q12.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
13-14 HS1 Q12.question: What vessels are the major sites of variable pressure and contribute to 60-70% of total pressure?
13-14 HS1 Q12.explanation:
*Arterioles* Note that arterioles are able to change their radius through intrinsic and extrinsic mechanisms. | | Vasoconstriction | Vasodilation | | --- | ----- | ----- | | Intrinsic | Myogenic:
Stretch
Metabolic:
Endothelins | Metabolic:
↑H+, CO2, K+
↓O2
Prostaglandin, Nitric oxide, Adenosine | | Extrinsic | Neuronal:
↑Sympathetic tone
Hormonal:
Angiotensin II, Antidiuretic hormone (ADH), Epinephrine, Norepinephrine | Neuronal:
↓Sympathetic tone
Hormonal:
Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) | Intrinsic mechanisms aims to vary the blood flow to individual tissues/organs, while extrinsic mechanisms aims to maintain the mean arterial pressure (MAP). As we have the Poiseuille’s equation: $R = \frac {8 \eta L} {\pi r^4}$ where $\eta$ = Viscosity of the blood, $L$ = Total length of blood vessel, $r$ =Internal radius of the vessel Hence changing $r$ from time-to-time will result in change of resistance, thus varying the change in blood flow rate/pressure. Meanwhile, arterioles itself, when combined with arteries, can contribute to 50 – 70% of total resistance/pressure of blood flow. It should be noted that the question will be more clear if asked in the following way: What vessels are the major sites of variable pressure resistance and contribute to 60-70% of total pressure resistance? It seems that the question is asking ‘pressure gradient’, instead of pressure itself. I.e. The higher the resistance, then the higher the pressure gradient across the blood vessel.

13-14 HS1 Q13.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
13-14 HS1 Q13.question: Which of the following is correct?

options.A: Cardiac output= heart rate x stroke volume

13-14 HS1 Q13.explanation:
*Cardiac output= heart rate x stroke volume*

Definitions: 
 * Cardiac output: Quantity of blood that the ventricles pump out per minute
 * Heart rate: No. of ventricular contraction per minute
 * Stroke volume: Volume of blood ejected by each ventricle per beat

Normal physiological values when at rest (Adult): 
 * HR = 70 beats/min
 * SV = 70 mL
 * CO = HR x SV = 5 L/min

13-14 HS1 Q15.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
13-14 HS1 Q15.question: What is the driving force for the blood flow in the systemic circuit?
13-14 HS1 Q15.explanation:
*Mean arterial pressure*  
  
Mean arterial pressure (MAP) is the pressure gradient between the aorta and the vena cava, responsible for driving blood flow in the systemic circuit.

13-14 HS1 Q22.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
13-14 HS1 Q22.question: Which of the following is incorrect?

options.A: Blood flow is controlled by pressure gradient.
options.B: Systemic circulation has higher pressure than pulmonary circulation.
options.C: Venous circulation contains most of the blood due to its larger diameter.
options.D: Lymphatic vessel does not involve in maintaining constant blood volume.

13-14 HS1 Q22.explanation:
*Lymphatic vessel does not involve in maintaining constant blood volume.*  
  
A. By the following equation:  
$F = \frac{\Delta P}{R}$
Note that the higher the pressure gradient $\Delta P$ then the higher the blood flow $F$ when resistance $R$ is unchanged.  
  
B. The $F_{systemic} = F_{pulmonary}$, to achieve so, note that $\Delta P_{systemic} > \Delta P_{pulmonary}$ and $R_{systemic} > R_{pulmonary}$ so that the blood flow rate in both circuits are the same.  
Note that $R_{systemic} > R_{pulmonary}$ because the length of the total blood vessel in the systemic circuit is much greater than that in the pulmonary circuit. Blood needs to overcome much more resistance, resulting in higher resistance in the systemic circuit.  
  
C. Veins are highly compliant, they can increase their diameter (holding more blood) with only small increase in pressure, and that they have lower tendencies to recoil back to their original shape (especially when the pressure decreases) compared to arteries.  
As a result, they can hold more blood at a low pressure due to larger diameter than arteries, and that veins are also called *blood reservoirs*.  
They hold around 60% of the total blood in human body.  
  
D. Some fluid in the capillary bed is drained into lymphatic capillaries (blind-end vessels) then  
travel through back the circulatory system via lymphatic system, i.e. the lymphatic system aids venous return to maintain a constant blood volume.

13-14 HS1 Q60.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
13-14 HS1 Q60.question: Which of the following most decrease the resistance of blood flow in a blood vessel?

options.A: decrease the vessel length by half
options.B: increase the vessel length by half
options.C: decrease the vessel diameter by half
options.D: increase the vessel diameter by half

13-14 HS1 Q60.explanation:
*increase the vessel diameter by half*  
  
As we have the Poiseuille’s equation:  
$R = \frac {8 \eta L} {\pi r^4}$
where $\eta$ = Viscosity of the blood, $L$ = Total length of blood vessel, $r$ =Internal radius of the vessel
By simple maths, increasing the vessel diameter by half (option D) has the greatest decrease in resistance of blood flow in the blood vessel.  
Note: the greatest decrease in resistance of blood flow would be the combination of option A (decrease the vessel length by half) and option D (increase the vessel diameter by half).

14-15 HS1 Q29.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
14-15 HS1 Q29.question: The likelihood of turbulent flow developing in a blood vessel can be predicted by a dimensionless number called the Reynold's number. The Reynold's number normally increases when

options.E: Percentage of red blood cell increases

14-15 HS1 Q29.explanation:
*Blood velocity increases*  
  
It can be deduced that the higher the Reynold’s number than the higher the P(turbulence).  
  
A. When blood velocity increases, molecules will bombard on the wall more vigorously, resulting in higher chance of turbulence.  
  
B. Increase in blood viscosity will result in molecules bombarding on the wall less vigorously, hence lower chance of turbulence.  
Thicker blood flows more slowly and resists chaotic movement.  
  
C. Smaller vessel diameters typically lead to smoother flow because the blood is confined to a narrow space.  
  
D. Lower density means the blood is lighter, which typically reduces the forces that could cause turbulence.  
  
E. This increase hematocrit (HCT) hence blood viscosity. See explanations of option B.  
  
Note that Reynold’s number Re = (ρ × v × D) / η where ρ = blood density, v = blood velocity, D = vessel diameter , η = blood viscosity. (For reference only)

14-15 HS1 Q30.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
14-15 HS1 Q30.question: Which of the following can increase the rate of blood flow in the blood vessel?

options.C: Increased pressure of the blood of the blood vessel
options.D: Deceased radius of the blood vessel
options.E: Increased length of the blood vessel

14-15 HS1 Q30.explanation:
*Increased pressure of the blood of the blood vessel*  
  
As we have the Poiseuille’s equation and the flow equation:

$R = \frac {8 \eta L} {\pi r^4}$ *and* $F = \frac{\Delta P}{R} \implies F = \frac{\Delta P \pi r^4}{8 \eta L}$

A. Constriction of blood vessel: $r \downarrow \implies F \downarrow$
B. Increased viscosity of the blood: $\eta \uparrow \implies F \downarrow$
C. Increased pressure of the blood of the blood vessel: $\Delta P \uparrow \implies F \uparrow$
D. Deceased radius of the blood vessel: $r \downarrow \implies F \downarrow$
E. Increased length of the blood vessel: $L \uparrow \implies F \downarrow$

It can be observed that option C is the only choice that can increase rate of blood flow $F$.

14-15 HS1 Q32.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
14-15 HS1 Q32.question: The driving force for systemic circuit:

options.A: right ventricular pressure - right atrial pressure
options.B: left ventricular pressure - left atrial pressure
options.E: left ventricular pressure - right ventricular pressure

14-15 HS1 Q32.explanation:
*Aortic pressure - Central venous pressure*  
  
This is also known as the mean arterial pressure (MAP) which describes the pressure gradient to drive blood flow within the systemic circuit.

15-16 HS1 Q27.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
15-16 HS1 Q27.question: What does not aid in venous return?
15-16 HS1 Q27.explanation:
*Increase in venous compliance*  
  
A: Venous valves help prevent backflow of blood due to pull of gravity, especially in lower limbs.
  
B: Increase in venous compliance will decrease venous pressure (as the same volume of blood can result in same enlargement of the vein with the smaller increase in pressure), and even result in more blood stored in veins. This results in reduced venous return to the right atrium.  
  
C: Inspiration creates negative thoracic pressure when diaphragm is flattened, which pulls blood towards the right atrium (↓P<sub>right atrial</sub> ⇒ P<sub>vein</sub> - P<sub>right atrial</sub>↑ ⇒ Venous return↑).  
  
A and D: Contraction of skeletal muscle + Venous valves ⇒ Musculovenous pump ⇒ Increase venous return

E: Increase in blood volume will increase overall blood pressure hence the pressure gradient.

15-16 HS1 Q44.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
15-16 HS1 Q44.question: Which of the following increases the resistance to blood flow?
15-16 HS1 Q44.explanation:
*Increase in viscosity*

  
As we have the Poiseuille’s equation: 
$R = \frac {8 \eta L} {\pi r^4}$
where $\eta$ = Viscosity of the blood, $L$ = Total length of blood vessel, $r$ =Internal radius of the vessel 
It can be easily observed that increase in viscosity will increase resistance $R$.  
  
A: Anemia decreases hematocrit as red blood cells typically has shorter lifespan, hence decrease viscosity of blood.  
  
C and D: Result in decrease of R.  
  
E: Polycythemia increases red blood cell density hence increase hematocrit, hence it also increase resistance to blood flow.  
However, option B provides a more direct solution, hence option E is not the best option.

16-17 HS1 Q7.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
16-17 HS1 Q7.question: Venous return refers to the return of deoxygenated blood in right atrium. Venous return is improved by venoconstriction due to sympathetic stimulation. Venoconstriction affects the venomotor tone and venous compliance by:

options.A: Increased venomotor tone and decreased venous compliance
options.B: Decreased venomotor tone and decreased venous compliance
options.C: Unchanged venomotor tone and increased venous compliance
options.D: Unchanged venomotor tone and decreased venous compliance
options.E: Both venomotor tone and venous compliance is increased

16-17 HS1 Q7.explanation:
*Increased venomotor tone and decreased venous compliance*  
  
Venomotor tone increases because the tension or tone of the venous walls increases. This increased tone helps to push blood towards the heart more efficiently.  
Meanwhile venoconstriction decreases venous compliance (as the expansion of the vein to the same extent requires larger pressure) hence **increases venous pressure**, resulting in **enhanced venous return** to the right atrium.  
This causes the **rise of end diastolic volume (EDV)** which **increases the stroke volume (SV)**, ultimately **increasing the cardiac output (CO)** hence the **mean arterial pressure (MAP) increases**.

16-17 HS1 Q8.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
16-17 HS1 Q8.question: Which of the following type of blood vessels is involved in the regulation of blood pressure and blood flow within a local organ?
16-17 HS1 Q8.explanation:
*Arteriole* Note that arterioles are able to change their radius through intrinsic and extrinsic mechanisms. | | Vasoconstriction | Vasodilation | | --- | ----- | ----- | | Intrinsic | Myogenic:
Stretch
Metabolic:
Endothelins | Metabolic:
↑H+, CO2, K+
↓O2
Prostaglandin, Nitric oxide, Adenosine | | Extrinsic | Neuronal:
↑Sympathetic tone
Hormonal:
Angiotensin II, Antidiuretic hormone (ADH), Epinephrine, Norepinephrine | Neuronal:
↓Sympathetic tone
Hormonal:
Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) | Intrinsic mechanisms aims to vary the blood flow to individual tissues/organs, while extrinsic mechanisms aims to maintain the mean arterial pressure (MAP). These mechanisms effectively regulate F (blood flow) as well as pressure (gradient) through changing the radius of the arterioles from time to time.

16-17 HS1 Q9.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
16-17 HS1 Q9.question: Laminar flow is common in normal circulatory system. However, it can be disrupted and become turbulent flow. Which of the following may cause turbulent flow?

options.D: When the blood velocity is high enough to break apart the laminar flow

16-17 HS1 Q9.explanation:
*All of the above* Note that turbulent flow is caused by 1) Blood flow is too rapid 2) Blood flow encounter irregular/rough surface 3) The blood flow is obstructed ⇒Typically occurs at branching points of large arteries, stenotic/narrowed, obstructed or diseases arteries, as well as across stenotic heart valves. Below are the major differences between laminar and turbulent flow: | Laminar flow | Turbulent flow | | ----- | ----- | | Flow is streamlined | Flow is disordered (not streamlined) | | Blood flows steadily through a long and smooth vessel | Blood flow becomes
1) Too great, and/or
2) Passes by an obstructed vessel/rough surface | | Tend to be silent | Tend to cause audible sound (murmur/bruit) in damaged/blocked blood vessel | | Velocity of flow in center of the vessel is greater (parabolic) because blood closer to the wall has more interaction with blood vessel wall (i.e. higher friction/resistance ⇒ move slower) | It can occur in large arteries at break points, in narrowed/stenotic, obstructed, or diseased arteries; across stenotic heart valves etc. |

16-17 HS1 Q12.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
16-17 HS1 Q12.question: Which of the following is a correct description of the dual circuit in heart?

options.A: The pressure gradient in driving the blood flow is the same in both circuits.
options.B: The flow rates in the two circuits are the same.
options.C: Total peripheral resistance is the sum of both circuits
options.D: The resistance in the pulmonary circuit is greater because of the surface tension in lungs.
options.E: The pressure gradient for systemic circuit is from right ventricular contraction.

16-17 HS1 Q12.explanation:
*The flow rates in the two circuits are the same.*  

The $F_{systemic} = F_{pulmonary}$, to achieve so, note that $\Delta P_{systemic} > \Delta P_{pulmonary}$ and $R_{systemic} > R_{pulmonary}$ so that the blood flow rate in both circuits are the same as we have the flow equation $F = \frac{\Delta P}{R}$. 
Note that $R_{systemic} > R_{pulmonary}$ because the length of the total blood vessel in the systemic circuit is much greater than that in the pulmonary circuit. Blood needs to overcome much more resistance, resulting in higher resistance in the systemic circuit.  
Pressure gradient for systemic circuit is from left ventricular contraction, while that of pulmonary circuit is from the right ventricular contraction.

17-18 HS1 Q24.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
17-18 HS1 Q24.question: Which of the following increase the resistance to blood flow?
17-18 HS1 Q24.explanation:
*Atherosclerosis*  
  
Note that atherosclerosis refers to the deposit of plaque on the inner blood vessel wall, resulting in the thickening and hardening of arteries.  
This result in the stenosis of arteries and decrease the inner radius of the blood vessel.  
By $R = \frac{8 \eta L}{\pi r^4}$ the resistance to blood flow increases.  
Note that aorta cannot undergo significant vasoconstriction because aorta is an elastic artery, hence option C is incorrect.

17-18 HS1 Q27.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
17-18 HS1 Q27.question:
Which of the following combinations correctly describes when haemodynamic of pulmonary circulation is compared with those of systemic circulation?

| Arterial Pressure | Resistance | Flow |
| ----- | ----- | ----- |
17-18 HS1 Q27.explanation:
| Arterial Pressure | Resistance | Flow |
| ----- | ----- | ----- |
| Lower | Lower | Same |

The $F_{systemic} = F_{pulmonary}$, to achieve so, note that $\Delta P_{systemic} > \Delta P_{pulmonary}$ and $R_{systemic} > R_{pulmonary}$ so that the blood flow rate in both circuits are the same as we have the flow equation $F = \frac{\Delta P}{R}$. 
Note that $R_{systemic} > R_{pulmonary}$ because the length of the total blood vessel in the systemic circuit is much greater than that in the pulmonary circuit. Blood needs to overcome much more resistance, resulting in higher resistance in the systemic circuit.

17-18 HS1 Q32.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
17-18 HS1 Q32.question: Laminar flow is common in normal circulatory system. However, it can be disrupted and becomes turbulent flow. Which of the following may cause turbulent flow?

options.D: When the blood velocity is high enough to break apart the laminar flow

17-18 HS1 Q32.explanation:
*All of the above* Note that turbulent flow is caused by 1) Blood flow is too rapid 2) Blood flow encounter irregular/rough surface 3) The blood flow is obstructed ⇒Typically occurs at branching points of large arteries, stenotic/narrowed, obstructed or diseases arteries, as well as across stenotic heart valves. Below are the major differences between laminar and turbulent flow: | Laminar flow | Turbulent flow | | ----- | ----- | | Flow is streamlined | Flow is disordered (not streamlined) | | Blood flows steadily through a long and smooth vessel | Blood flow becomes
1) Too great, and/or
2) Passes by an obstructed vessel/rough surface | | Tend to be silent | Tend to cause audible sound (murmur/bruit) in damaged/blocked blood vessel | | Velocity of flow in center of the vessel is greater (parabolic) because blood closer to the wall has more interaction with blood vessel wall (i.e. higher friction/resistance ⇒ move slower) | It can occur in large arteries at break points, in narrowed/stenotic, obstructed, or diseased arteries; across stenotic heart valves etc. |

17-18 HS1 Q35.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
17-18 HS1 Q35.question: Venous return to the right atrium is improved by venoconstriction due to sympathetic stimulation. Venoconstriction affects the venomotor tone and venous compliance by:

options.A: Venomotor tone increases and venous compliance decreases
options.B: Venomotor tone decreases and venous compliance decreases
options.C: Venomotor tone remains unchanged while venous compliance increases
options.D: Venomotor tone remains unchanged while venous compliance decreases
options.E: Both venomotor tone and venous compliance increase.

17-18 HS1 Q35.explanation:
*Venomotor tone increases and venous compliance decreases*  
  
Venomotor tone increases because the tension or tone of the venous walls increases. This increased tone helps to push blood towards the heart more efficiently.  
Meanwhile venoconstriction decreases venous compliance (as the expansion of the vein to the same extent requires larger pressure) hence increases venous pressure, resulting in enhanced venous return to the right atrium.  
This causes the rise of end diastolic volume (EDV) which increases the stroke volume (SV), ultimately increasing the cardiac output (CO) hence the mean arterial pressure (MAP) increases.

18-19 HS2 Q39.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
18-19 HS2 Q39.question: Which blood vessel contributes the most to the total systemic pressure?
18-19 HS2 Q39.explanation:
*Elastic artery*  
  
Elastic arteries are <u>pressure reservoirs</u> because when blood of high pressure passes through then the elastic arteries can distend (storing up the pressure) and distend at a later time and release the pressure toe the blood in the lumen to ensure that blood flow is smoothly. Hence this maintains the systemic pressure.  
Meanwhile arterioles are also known as <u>resistance vessels</u> because they are the source of most resistance to flow within the vascular system. They are composed of <u>mostly smooth muscles</u>. This is similar for muscular artery except that arterioles contain more smooth muscle cells than muscular arteries.  
  
Note that there are three main functions of arterioles:  
1. Source of most resistance to flow in vascular system  
2. Determine distribution/re-distribution of blood flow to organs and tissues (through local control mechanisms)

3. Major determinants of mean arterial pressure (MAP) as it affects the total peripheral resistance (TPR) as given by the equation MAP = CO x TPR (where CO is the cardiac output)

18-19 HS2 Q40.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
18-19 HS2 Q40.question: The following factors would increase peripheral resistance except one. Identify the exception.

options.B: Elevated level in blood epinephrine level (adrenaline)
options.D: Irregularities in vessel walls caused by plaque

18-19 HS2 Q40.explanation:
*Vasodilation*  
  
A. Increasing sympathetic stimulation can result in vasoconstriction of the arterioles hence decreasing the internal radius of the arterioles. Total peripheral resistance increases as a result.  
  
B. Adrenaline also stimulates vasoconstriction of the arterioles.  
  
C. Vasodilation increases the internal radius of the arterioles hence decreases total peripheral resistance.  
  
D. This decreases the internal radius of blood vessels.  
  
E. This increases blood viscosity. Resistance to blood flow increases as a result.  
Note that polycythaemia is an example of increasing hematocrit (HCT).  
Note that hypothermia as well as extreme dehydration will also increase hematocrit.

18-19 HS2 Q41.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
18-19 HS2 Q41.question: In normal condition, blood flow through a blood vessel is 100ml/min with a pressure gradient of 50 mmHg. What is the approximate flow through a vessel when the vessel radius is increased by 50% assuming the pressure gradient remains unchanged at 50 mmHg?
18-19 HS2 Q41.explanation:
*500ml/min*  
  
As we have the Poiseuille’s equation and the flow equation:

$R = \frac {8 \eta L} {\pi r^4}$ *and* $F = \frac{\Delta P}{R} \implies F = \frac{\Delta P \pi r^4}{8 \eta L}$

It can be observed that F ∝ r<sup>4</sup> when other parameters are kept constant.  
F<sub>new</sub> = F<sub>o</sub> x 1.5<sup>4</sup> = 5.0625 F<sub>o</sub> ~ 5F<sub>o</sub>

18-19 HS2 Q42.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
18-19 HS2 Q42.question: Which blood vessel has the highest tendency for turbulent blood flow?
18-19 HS2 Q42.explanation:
*Aorta*  
  
Note that turbulent blood flow occurs at points where:  
1. Blood flow is very fast that the <u>blood velocity is high enough to break apart the laminar flow</u> aorta  
2. Branching points of large arteries, narrowed/stenotic, obstructed or diseased arteries  
3. Across stenotic heart valves rough surface

19-20 HS2 Q4.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
19-20 HS2 Q4.question: If during an aerobic exercise (e.g. jogging), cardiac output doubles and systemic resistance decreases by half (50%), what will happen to mean arterial pressure (MAP) assuming central venous pressure is always close to zero?
19-20 HS2 Q4.explanation:
*MAP does not change*  
  
MAP = TPR x CO where MAP = mean arterial pressure, TPR = total peripheral resistance and CO = cardiac output  
MAP<sub>new</sub> = TPR<sub>new</sub> x CO<sub>new</sub> = (0.5TPR<sub>o</sub>) (2CO<sub>o</sub>) =TPR<sub>o</sub> x CO<sub>o</sub> = MAP<sub>o</sub>

19-20 HS2 Q5.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
19-20 HS2 Q5.question: If an artery becomes diseased and its diameter is reduced by 75%, resistance along that artery will be increased?
19-20 HS2 Q5.explanation:
*256-fold*  
  
By Poiseuille’s equation:  
$R = \frac {8 \eta L} {\pi r^4}$

$R \varpropto \frac{1}{r^4}$ when other factors kept constant, hence when r<sub>new</sub> = 0.25r<sub>old</sub>, R<sub>new</sub> = 256R<sub>old</sub>

19-20 HS2 Q7.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
19-20 HS2 Q7.question:
Which of the following statement(s) about arterioles is/are correct?

i. Arterioles are considered part of the resistance vasculature that provides in excess of 50% of the resistance to blood flow in our body

ii. Arterioles are considered part of the resistance vasculature that provides in excess of 80% of the resistance to blood flow in our body

iii. Arterioles are the main sites of variable resistance in the systemic circuit

iv. Arterioles in individual organs determines the relative blood flow to those organs at any given systolic blood pressure
19-20 HS2 Q7.explanation:
*ii, iii and iv*  
  
Arterioles (together with small arteries) are considered part of the resistance vasculature that results in around 50% to 70% of the **pressure drop**. (From lecture slides)

However, from google, as well as other senior’s sources, arterioles provide around 80% of the **resistance** to blood flow in our body. (Not from lecture slides) ii is correct and i is incorrect  
Arterioles are the main sites of variable resistance in the systemic circuit as they can vary their radius to do so through vasoconstriction or vasodilation. iii is correct

Arterioles are able to determine the relative blood flow to local organs by vasoconstriction or vasodilation. But if we mentioned blood flow only, this statement is also true. iv is correct

19-20 HS2 Q31.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
19-20 HS2 Q31.question: If other factors are equal, which of the following blood vessels would have the lowest resistance?
19-20 HS2 Q31.explanation:
*Length = 0.5cm, radius = 2 cm*  
  
By Poiseuille’s equation:  
$R = \frac {8 \eta L} {\pi r^4}$
The larger the radius and the smaller the length then the lower the resistance to blood flow.

19-20 HS2 Q32.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
19-20 HS2 Q32.question:
The compliance curves for two blood vessels namely vessel A and B are depicted below. Which of the following options correctly describe the two curves?

![](img/19-20_HS2_Q32_1754753813631.png)

 i. Vessel A has a greater compliance than vessel B
 ii. Vessel B has a greater compliance than vessel A
 iii. Vascular smooth muscle contraction in A will shift its curve downward
 iv. Vascular smooth muscle contraction in B will shift its curve downward
 v. Vessel A is an artery and vessel B is a vein
19-20 HS2 Q32.explanation:
*i, iii and iv*  
  
Definition of compliance is how easy a lumen of a blood vessel expands when it is filled with a volume of blood.  
Note that compliance $C = \frac{\Delta V}{\Delta P}$ and it can be easily observed that vessel A has a higher compliance.  
i is correct and ii is incorrect

Hence vessel A is vein while vessel B is artery. v is incorrect  
When vasoconstriction note that the compliance of the vessel will decreases. This is because it will be more difficult for the blood vessel to distend when there is an increase in volume. This also implies that the curve would be shifted downwards. iii and iv are correct  
However, it should be noted that arteries (especially elastic arteries) only have some smooth muscle cells (i.e. not significant), hence they are not able to undergo significant vasoconstriction. This statement is only true it vessel B is a muscular artery. iv **may be** correct only, but **not necessarily** true

19-20 HS2 Q42.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
19-20 HS2 Q42.question: Which of the following statements regarding blood pressure, blood volume and blood flow is INCORRECT?

options.A: Arterial pressure is a balance between cardiac output and the resistance to blood flow offered by the arterioles
options.B: If heart rate increases, the relative time spent on diastole decreases. As a result, the contribution of systolic pressure to MAP decreases.
options.C: Veins hold more than half of the blood in the circulatory system
options.D: The rapid pressure rise that occurs when the left ventricle pushes blood into the aorta can be felt as a pressure wave or a pulse
options.E: Exchange of materials between blood and the interstitial fluid occurs primarily by diffusion

19-20 HS2 Q42.explanation:
*If heart rate increases, the relative time spent on diastole decreases. As a result, the contribution of systolic pressure to MAP decreases.*  
  
A: By MAP = CO x TPR, this statement is true.  
  
B: Systolic pressure increases with a higher heart rate due to stronger cardiac output.  
Contribution of systolic pressure to MAP increases.  
  
C: True due to the high compliance of veins.  
  
D: True. The pulse felt in arteries is caused by the pressure wave generated during systole when the left ventricle ejects blood into the aorta.

19-20 HS2 Q59.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
19-20 HS2 Q59.question:
Which statement(s) regarding the systemic and pulmonary circuit is/are correct?

i.  The blood flow is greater through the systemic circuit
ii.  The blood flow is greater through the pulmonary circuit
iii.  The absolute pressure is greater in the systemic circuit
iv.  The blood flow is the same in both circuits
v.  The pressure gradient is the same in both circuits
19-20 HS2 Q59.explanation:
*iii and iv*  
  
The F<sub>systemic</sub> = F<sub>pulmonary </sub> i and ii are incorrect, iv is correct, to achieve so, note that $\Delta P_{systemic} > \Delta P_{pulmonary}$ iii is correct and v is incorrect and R<sub>systemic</sub> > R<sub>pulmonary </sub> so that the blood flow rate in both circuits are the same as we have the flow equation $F = \frac{\Delta P}{R}$.  
Note that R<sub>systemic</sub> > R<sub>pulmonary </sub> because the length of the total blood vessel in the systemic circuit is much greater than that in the pulmonary circuit. Blood needs to overcome much more resistance, resulting in higher resistance in the systemic circuit.

20-21 HS2 Q38.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
20-21 HS2 Q38.question:
Which of the following statements about arterioles is/are correct?

i. Arterioles are considered part of resistance vasculature that provides excess of 50% of resistance to blood flow in our body

ii. Arterioles are considered part of resistance vasculature that provides excess of 80% of resistance to blood flow in our body

iii. Arterioles are the main sites of variable resistance in systemic circuit

iv. Arterioles in individual organs determine blood flow to those organs at any given systolic pressure
20-21 HS2 Q38.explanation:
*ii, iii and iv*  
  
Arterioles (together with small arteries) are considered part of the resistance vasculature that results in around 50% to 70% of the **pressure drop**. (From lecture slides)

However, from google, as well as other senior’s sources, arterioles provide around 80% of the **resistance** to blood flow in our body. (Not from lecture slides) ii is correct and i is incorrect  
Arterioles are the main sites of variable resistance in the systemic circuit as they can vary their radius to do so through vasoconstriction or vasodilation. iii is correct

Arterioles are able to determine the relative blood flow to local organs by vasoconstriction or vasodilation. But if we mentioned blood flow only, this statement is also true. iv is correct

20-21 HS2 Q39.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
20-21 HS2 Q39.question:
The compliance curves for two blood vessels namely vessel A and vessel B are depicted below. Which of the following options correctly describes the two curves?

![](img/20-21_HS2_Q39_1754753813632.png)

i. Vessel A has higher compliance than B

ii. Vessel B has higher compliance than A

iii. Vascular smooth muscle contraction in A will shift its curve downwards

iv. Vascular smooth muscle contraction in B will shift its curve downwards

v. Vessel A is an artery and vessel B is a vein
20-21 HS2 Q39.explanation:
*i, iii and iv*  
  
Definition of compliance is how easy a lumen of a blood vessel expands when it is filled with a volume of blood.  
Note that compliance $C = \frac{\Delta V}{\Delta P}$ and it can be easily observed that vessel A has a higher compliance.  
i is correct and ii is incorrect

Hence vessel A is vein while vessel B is artery. v is incorrect  
When vasoconstriction note that the compliance of the vessel will decreases. This is because it will be more difficult for the blood vessel to distend when there is an increase in volume. This also implies that the curve would be shifted downwards. iii and iv are correct  
However, it should be noted that arteries (especially elastic arteries) only have some smooth muscle cells, hence they are not able to undergo significant vasoconstriction. This statement is only more true if vessel B is a muscular artery/arteriole. iv **may be** correct only, but **not necessarily** true

21-22 HS2 Q39.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
21-22 HS2 Q39.question: Which of the following about veins is correct?

options.A: Contraction of smooth muscle decreases compliance and increases pressure
options.B: Sympathetic stimulation increases the lumen size to maintain venous return
options.C: The walls mainly contain smooth muscle that is under both sympathetic and parasympathetic control
options.D: They are very compliant and hold around 30% of blood

21-22 HS2 Q39.explanation:
*Contraction of smooth muscle decreases compliance and increases pressure*  
  
A. Contraction of smooth muscle results in venoconstriction, hence decrease compliance. Also venous pressure increases as larger pressure is needed to expand the lumen of the vein to the same extent to hold the same volume of blood. Note that this can improve venous return to right atrium, resulting in the increase in MAP.  
  
B. Sympathetic stimulation will result in contraction of smooth muscle hence decrease lumen size.  
  
C. Walls only under sympathetic control but not parasympathetic control.  
  
D. They hold around 60% of blood.  
  
E. Constriction improves venous return, which in other words, enhances mean arterial pressure (MAP) hence improves systemic blood flow.

21-22 HS2 Q40.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
21-22 HS2 Q40.question: Local blood flow is affected by chemicals of metabolism. Which of the following increases the local blood flow to an organ?
21-22 HS2 Q40.explanation:
An increase in CO2 Note that increases local blood flow to an organ implies vasodilation. Note that arterioles are able to change their radius through intrinsic and extrinsic mechanisms. | | Vasoconstriction | Vasodilation | | --- | ----- | ----- | | Intrinsic | Myogenic:
Stretch
Metabolic:
Endothelins | Metabolic:
↑H+, CO2, K+
↓O2
Prostaglandin, Nitric oxide, Adenosine | | Extrinsic | Neuronal:
↑Sympathetic tone
Hormonal:
Angiotensin II, Antidiuretic hormone (ADH), Epinephrine, Norepinephrine | Neuronal:
↓Sympathetic tone
Hormonal:
Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) | Significance of vasodilation: Remove CO2 more rapidly from local tissues/organs.

21-22 HS2 Q41.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
21-22 HS2 Q41.question: Which of the following is/are not active in vasoconstriction and acts mainly as pressure reservoir?
21-22 HS2 Q41.explanation:
*Aorta and elastic artery*  
  
They acts as pressure reservoir because they contain thick bands of elastic fibers. When the left ventricle contracts which force blood of high pressure to the aorta/elastic artery, they distend and store the pressure in elastic walls. They will distend when the left ventricles relax to provide force to maintain smooth unidirectional blood flow towards the systemic circuit.

Muscular artery contain thicker smooth muscles and less elastic fibers and they are responsible for providing resistance to blood flow instead of acting as pressure reservoirs.

21-22 HS2 Q42.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
21-22 HS2 Q42.question: Which of the following statements regarding blood pressure, blood volume and blood flow is INCORRECT?

options.A: Arterial pressure is a balance between cardiac output and the resistance to blood flow offered by the arterioles.
options.B: Exchange of materials between the blood and the interstitial fluid occurs primarily by diffusion.
options.C: If heart rate increases, the relative time spent in diastole decreases. As a result, the contribution of systolic pressure to mean arterial pressure (MAP) decreases.
options.D: The rapid pressure rise that occurs when the left ventricle pushes blood into the aorta can be felt as a pressure wave or pulse.
options.E: Veins hold more than half of the blood in the circulatory system.

21-22 HS2 Q42.explanation:
*If heart rate increases, the relative time spent in diastole decreases. As a result, the contribution of systolic pressure to mean arterial pressure (MAP) decreases.*  
  
A: By MAP = CO x TPR, this is true.  
  
B: True.  
  
C: Contribution of systolic pressure to MAP should increases. Note that the first half of the statement *relative time spent in diastole decreases* is true.  
  
D: True.  
  
E: Veins hold around 60% of the total blood in the circulatory system due to the high compliance of veins.

22-23 HS2 Q14.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
22-23 HS2 Q14.question: Which of the following best describes the effect of blood pressure and resistance on the local tissues?

options.A: Decreased blood pressure that results in the vasoconstriction of the arterioles.
options.B: Increased blood pressure that results in the vasodilation of the arterioles.
options.C: Increased blood pressure that drives blood flow to local tissues.
options.D: Increased metabolic activity that results in the vasoconstriction of the arterioles.
options.E: Increased metabolic activity that results in the vasodilation of the arterioles.

22-23 HS2 Q14.explanation:
*Increased metabolic activity that results in the vasodilation of the arterioles.*  
  
Increased metabolic activities reduces O<sub>2</sub> content while increasing CO<sub>2</sub> thus stimulating vasodilation via intrinsic mechanisms.  
Note that increase in blood pressure will stretch the arterioles hence result in vasoconstriction. This is myogenic response.

22-23 HS2 Q15.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
22-23 HS2 Q15.question: Which of the following is a result of increased sympathetic stimulation of vascular smooth muscle?

options.A: Decrease blood flow to the brain
options.B: Filtration of fluid from capillaries to interstitial fluid increases

22-23 HS2 Q15.explanation:
*Venous return increases*  
  
Increased sympathetic stimulation will cause venoconstriction hence decrease in compliance of veins, resulting in increase in venous pressure hence improved venous return. This in turn increases the end diastolic volume (EDV) which increases stroke volume (SV) hence cardiac output (CO), resulting in the increase in mean arterial pressure (MAP). % of blood in veins decreases.  
Sympathetic stimulation generally increases TPR due to vasoconstriction in arterioles.  
Meanwhile sympathetic stimulation generally increases blood pressure. This is because

MAP = CO x TPR

As TPR increases hence MAP also increases.  
Increase in MAP maintains or increases blood flow to vital organs like the brain.

Meanwhile, note that the sympathetic stimulation will also result in vasoconstriction of the arterioles, hence reducing the downstream pressure/reducing perfusion pressure. The hydrostatic pressure gradient between tissue fluid and capillaries decreases, reducing the fluid filtration rate.

22-23 HS2 Q16.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
22-23 HS2 Q16.question:
Consider the following equation:  

$F = \frac{\Delta P}{R}$
  
There is fluid flow (*F*) in a tube where there is a pressure difference (ΔP) between the two ends and resistance I to flow. Based on the equation, which of the following is correct?

options.A: When both resistance and pressure difference increase, the flow of fluid increases.
options.B: The flow of fluid depends on the absolute pressure at the beginning of the tube.
options.C: When the resistance increases, the flow of fluid increases for any pressure difference.
options.D: The flow of fluid decreases when the resistance decreases.
options.E: The flow of fluid increases when the pressure at the beginning of the tube increases, while that at the end of the tube stays the same or decreases

22-23 HS2 Q16.explanation:
*The flow of fluid increases when the pressure at the beginning of the tube increases, while that at the end of the tube stays the same or decreases*  
  
This means that ΔP increases while R remains unchanged, hence flow *F* increases.

22-23 HS2 Q17.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
22-23 HS2 Q17.question:
The relationship between volume and pressure is termed as the compliance curve of the vessel. Select the statements which correctly describe the functional properties of the two blood vessels.

![](img/22-23_HS2_Q17_1754753813633.png)

i. The compliance of the vein at low pressures is higher than the artery

ii. Compliance decreases at higher pressures and volumes for both the artery and the vein

iii. Reduced vascular compliance will shift the volume-pressure curves downwards for both the artery and the vein
22-23 HS2 Q17.explanation:
*i, ii and iii*  
  
Note that vessel A is vein while vessel B is artery.  
Statement i is definitely true.  
Note that the curve eventually plateaus off at high pressures and volumes, indicating a decrease in compliance because slope of the volume-pressure curve equals to compliance. Hence statement ii is also true.  
The reduced in vascular compliance (brought by constriction of the blood vessels) will result in the slope decreases, similar to shifting down of the curves. Hence statement iii is also true.

23-24 HS2 MID-TERM Q1.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
23-24 HS2 MID-TERM Q1.question: What is the pressure reservoir in cardiovascular system?
23-24 HS2 MID-TERM Q1.explanation:
*Aorta*  
  
Femoral artery, radial artery and brachial artery are muscular arteries which have lower proportion of elastic fibers (and thicker smooth muscles) hence they are not pressure reservoirs as they do not distend and recoil significantly.

23-24 HS2 MID-TERM Q20.topic: Lecture 4 - Force, pressure and elasticity I
23-24 HS2 MID-TERM Q20.question: Binding to which of the following receptors will cause contraction of vascular smooth muscles?
23-24 HS2 MID-TERM Q20.explanation:
*Alpha*  
  
Note that for sympathetic stimulation (extrinsic mechanism), the norepinephrine binds to the  
α-adrenergic receptors to initiate constriction of the vascular smooth muscles.

12-13 HS1 Q41.question: Baroreceptors is located at
12-13 HS1 Q41.explanation:
Locations of baroreceptors: 
 * Aortic arch
 * Carotid sinus

-> Send to medulla oblongata (of brainstem)

13-14 HS1 Q14.question: The integration centre of neural control of blood pressure is located in
13-14 HS1 Q14.explanation:
Medulla oblongata participates in **arterial baroreceptor reflex** by acting as **control center / integrating center**

Effectors: SA node, myocardium (esp. ventricles), arterioles, veins
Receptors: Arterial baroreceptors (Detect **sudden** change in MAP)

13-14 HS1 Q23.question: The heart contains the following except
13-14 HS1 Q23.explanation:
A. Myocardium: For myocardial contraction

B. Pacemaker cell: SA, AV nodes (autorhythmicity)
Together with conduction fibers to form intrinsic conduction system

D. Autonomic nerve terminal: For autonomic regulation
Parasympathetic supply (Ach) only innervate atria (muscarinic-type acetylcholine receptors)
Sympathetic supply (Norepinephrine) innervate both atria and ventricles (beta adrenergic receptors)

E. Blood vessels: Coronary vessels supply & drain blood to / from myocardium
(Blocked -> myocardial infarction)

13-14 HS1 Q58.question: Which of the component of the ECG represents ventricle depolarization?

14-15 HS1 Q31.question: During isovolumetric relaxation,

options.A: AV and semilunar valves open, ventricular pressure increases
options.B: AV and semilunar valves open, ventricular pressure decreases
options.C: AV and semilunar valves close, ventricular pressure increase.
options.D: AV and semilunar valves close, ventricular pressure decrease
options.E: AV valve open, semilunar valve close, ventricular pressure decrease

14-15 HS1 Q31.explanation:
During isovolumetric relaxation, 

Ventricles start to relax ⇒ **Ventricular pressure↓**

⇒ P<sub>atrium</sub> < P<sub>ventricle</sub> < P<sub>aorta / pulmonary artery</sub>

P<sub>atrium</sub> < P<sub>ventricle</sub> ⇒ **AV valve closes** ⇒ No blood from atria to ventricles

P<sub>ventricle</sub> < P<sub>aorta / pulmonary artery</sub> ⇒ **Semilunar valve closes** ⇒ No blood ejected from ventricles

14-15 HS1 Q33.question:
Systole 110 diastole 70, what is MAP and pulse pressure?
*(Input the values in 3 significant figures if needed, use a comma followed by a single space character to separate the values)*
14-15 HS1 Q33.explanation:
Mean arterial pressure

= $\frac 1 3$ Systolic pressure + $\frac 2 3$ Diastolic pressure

= $\frac 1 3 \times 110 + \frac 2 3 \times 70$

= $\frac {250} 3$

= $83.3$ mmHg

Pulse pressure
= 110 - 70 = 40 mmHg

14-15 HS1 Q34.question: Which ion is responsible for the depolarization of pacemaker cell in the heart?
14-15 HS1 Q34.explanation:
![](img/14-15_HS1_Q34_1755442058561.png) | Phase | Ion channel gating | Ion movement | ----- | ----- | ----- | | Phase 4 - Pacemaker potential / Spontaneous depolarization | Funny channels open
T-type Ca2+ channels open | Na+ influx↑
Ca2+ influx↑ | | Phase 0 - Rapid depolarization | L-type Ca2+ channels open | Ca2+ influx↑ | | Phase 3 - Repolarization | K+ channels open | K+ efflux↑ | The **spontaneous** depolarization of pacemaker cells contribute to the autorhythmicity.

14-15 HS1 Q36.question: The second heart sound occurs when semilunar valves close and thus it marks
14-15 HS1 Q36.explanation:
The end of ejection period, i.e. isovolumetric relaxation

\* Both AV and semilunar valve close during this period

15-16 HS1 Q26.question:
Transmission of cardiac signal sequence

I. Bundle of His
II. Internodal Pathway
III. Purkinje’s fibre
IV. AV node
V. SA node
VI. Left and right ventricular bundle
 
*(List the sequence in chronological order, use a comma followed by a single space character to separate the answers)*
15-16 HS1 Q26.answer: V, II, IV, I, VI, III
15-16 HS1 Q26.explanation:
AV node: 
* Slowest conduction velocity (about 0.05 ms<sup>-1</sup>)
* Propagation of AP through AV node requires **AV nodal delay** (0.1s) to allow atrial contraction to be completed before ventricular excitation occurs. 

Purkinje fibers:
* Highest conduction velocity (about 4 ms<sup>-1</sup>)
* Transmit AP to ventricular myocardial cells

15-16 HS1 Q28.question: What is the ejection fraction of a healthy person?
15-16 HS1 Q28.explanation:
Ejection fraction (EF) =Index of cardiac contractility, calculating % of EDV pump

$EF = \frac {SV} {EDV}$
SV: Can heart eject enough blood out?
EDV: Volume of blood in ventricles just prior to systole

Normal value: >50%
Cardiac failure: <30%

EF can be measured by imaging techniques such as **echocardiography** (cardiac ultrasound)

16-17 HS1 Q19.question:
Find the ejection fraction of a 30-year-old male with the following information:

End diastolic volume : 120mL
End systolic volume : 50mL
Cardiac output : 4.9L/min
Heart rate : 70/min

*(Input the value in 3 significant figures)*
16-17 HS1 Q19.explanation:
Ejection fraction: Index of cardiac contractility (heart contractile function)

Ejection fraction

= Stroke volume / End diastolic volume

= $\frac {EDV-ESV} {EDV}$

= $\frac {70} {120}$

= $58.3 \%$

or

Ejection fraction

= Stroke volume / End diastolic volume

= $\frac {CO} {HR} \times \frac {1} {EDV}$

= $\frac {4900} {70} \times \frac {1} {120}$

= $\frac {70} {120}$

= $58.3 \%$

16-17 HS1 Q20.question: In the rapid depolarization phase of the action potential in sinoatrial node, these are open:
16-17 HS1 Q20.explanation:
Funny Na<sup>+</sup> channels are open during initial period of pacemaker potential, while T-type Ca<sup>2+</sup> channels are open during latter period of pacemaker potential
⇒ Slow depolarization

16-17 HS1 Q21.question: The open and closure of AV valves and semilunar valves is driven by

options.B: contraction of muscles attached to valves
options.C: the contraction of ventricles and atria ...
options.D: the difference in pressure across valves
options.E: both Contraction and relaxation of valves

16-17 HS1 Q21.explanation:
A. Contraction of valve *Incorrect*
Valves do not contract or relax. 

B. Contraction of muscles attached to valves *Incorrect*
The muscles attached to valves are known as papillary muscles ⇒ Contract to tighten chordae tendineae to prevent AV valves from everting when ventricles contract

C. Contraction of ventricles and atria *Incorrect*
Contraction and relaxation of ventricles and atria eventually leads to the open and closure of valves, but it is not the direct reason. 

D. **Difference in pressure across valves *Correct***
Contraction and relaxation of ventricles and atria create the pressure gradient, which leads to the open and closure of AV valves and semilunar valves. 

E. Both contraction and relaxation of valves *Incorrect*
Valves do not contract or relax.

17-18 HS1 Q26.question: If there is blood loss sufficient to cause a decrease in mean arterial pressure, which of the following is TRUE?

options.A: Coronary sinus venous activity would be increased
options.C: Total peripheral resistance would be decreased
options.D: Heart rate would be decreased to save energy of nodal cells
options.E: Cardiac contractility would be decreased to reduce the burden of the myocardium

17-18 HS1 Q26.explanation:
A. Coronary sinus venous activity would be increased *Incorrect*
It will not increase significantly

B. **Sympathetic activity would be increased *Correct***
Decrease in baroreceptors firing rate detected by medulla oblongata ⇒ Increased sympathetic activity

C. Total peripheral resistance would be decreased *Incorrect*
TPR would be increased due to vasoconstriction of arterioles

D. Heart rate would be decreased to save energy of nodal cells *Incorrect*
Heart rate would be increased as SA node fire AP more rapidly

E. Cardiac contractility would be decreased to reduce the burden of the myocardium *Incorrect*
Cardiac contractility would be increased to increase stroke volume, i.e. volume of blood ejected by each ventricle per beat

17-18 HS1 Q34.question: Atropine is a drug that blocks the action of acetylcholine--a neurotransmitter released at parasympathetic nerve endings. Under the effect of atropine, which of the following statements is true?

options.C: The contractility of the heart decreases.
options.D: The contractility of the heart increases.
options.E: Both the heart rate and the contractility of the heart decrease.

17-18 HS1 Q34.explanation:
* Effect on heart rate:
Parasympathetic supply↓ ⇒ Suppress heart rate effect↓ ⇒ Heart rate↑

* Effect on cardiac contractility
Mainly dependent on sympathetic supply as **ventricles do not receive parasympathetic supply**
Hence only increase contractility of atrium (not very significant impact on overall cardiac output) ⇒ D not best answer

Note:
Besides increase in HR, conduction velocity of AP also increases

17-18 HS1 Q36.question: When will the aortic pressure be the greatest during cardiac cycle?

options.C: At the beginning of the rapid ventricular filling

17-18 HS1 Q36.explanation:
![](img/17-18_HS1_Q36_1755595569681.png)

During ventricular systole / ejection (grey area), aortic valves open

During diastole (white area), aortic valves close

18-19 HS2 Q43.question: During the rapid depolarization phase of action potentials of myocardial contractile cells, which of the following ion(s) is/are moving across the membrane?
18-19 HS2 Q43.explanation:
![](img/18-19_HS2_Q43_1755597307901.png) | Phase | Ion channel gating | | ----- | ----- | | Phase 0: Rapid depolarization | Na+ channels open | | Phase 1: Small repolarization | Na+ channels inactivated | | Phase 2: Plateau | Ca2+ L-type channels open
K+ channels close | | Phase 3: Repolarization | Ca2+ L-type channels close
K+ channels open | | Phase 4: RMP | K+ channels open
Na+, Ca2+ channels remain close |

19-20 HS2 Q13.question: A sudden fall in arterial blood pressure as occurs when a person rapidly stands up causes a/an

options.A: Vasodilation of systemic blood vessels to maintain blood flow
options.B: Increase in firing of the arterial baroreceptors
options.C: Increase in the rate of SA node firing
options.D: Stimulation of the thirst receptor to retain more water
options.E: Increases in the delay duration at the AV node

19-20 HS2 Q13.explanation:
The phenomenon is known as **Postural hypotension / Orthostatic hypotension**

Sudden change from supine to standing position
⇒ Blood pools in the veins
⇒ Venous return↓
⇒ CO↓
⇒ MAP↓ (sudden drop)
⇒ Detected by arterial baroreceptors
⇒ Cardiovascular center at medulla received
⇒ Sympathetic activity↑, Parasympathetic activity↓

A. Vasodilation of systemic blood vessels *Incorrect*
Sympathetic supply↑ ⇒ More noradrenaline bind to α-receptors of smooth muscles ⇒ **Vasoconstriction**

B. Increase in firing of the arterial baroreceptors *Incorrect*
Decreased MAP ⇒ **Decrease** in firing of baroreceptors

C. **Increase in the rate of SA node firing *Correct***
Parasympathetic supply↓ ⇒ **Increased** AP frequency of SA node

D. Stimulation of the thirst receptor to retain more water *Incorrect*
**Thirst reflex**, instead of thirst receptors, will be stimulated
Arterial baroreceptors ⇒ Stimulate thirst sensation (only if ↓MAP significant) and Angiotensin II ↑ (RAAS)

E. Increase in the delay duration at the AV node *Incorrect*
Increased conduction velocity of intrinsic conduction system ⇒ **Decrease** in the delay duration at the AV node

19-20 HS2 Q20.question: Which of the following statements about the electrical and mechanical events in the cardiac cycle is INCORRECT?

options.A: Atrial contraction occurs at the very end of diastole adds only a small amount of additional blood to the ventricles
options.B: Action potential must be initiated in cardiac cells for contraction to occur
options.C: The amount of blood in the ventricles just before systole is the EDV
options.D: The first heart sound is due to the closures of the aortic and pulmonary valves
options.E: The SA node manifests a pacemaker potential involving voltage-gated cation channels, which brings its membrane potential to threshold and triggers an action potential

19-20 HS2 Q20.explanation:
A. Atrial contraction occurs at the very end of diastole adds only a small amount of additional blood to the ventricles *Correct*
Atrial contraction only contributes to 10% of the ventricular filling for maximizing the EDV
Most of the blood fill up the ventricles **passively**

B. AP must be initiated in cardiac cells for contraction to occur *Correct*
Myocardial cells: Have true RMP
SA node: Spontaneous depolarization

C. The amount of blood in the ventricles just before systole is the EDV *Correct*
By definition
Stroke volume = EDV - ESV

D. **The first heart sound is due to the closures of the aortic and pulmonary valves *Incorrect***
Closures of the atrioventricular valves (AV, mitral & tricuspid valves) ⇒ First heart sound
Closures of the semilunar valves (aortic & pulmonary valves) ⇒ Second heart sound

E. Phase 4 - Pacemaker potential: 
Funny channels for Na<sup>+</sup> influx (activated by hyperpolarization)
T-type Ca<sup>2+</sup> channels for Ca<sup>2+</sup> influx (activated by depolarization)

19-20 HS2 Q21.question: The T wave of ECG begins to occur during
19-20 HS2 Q21.explanation:
T wave of ECG represent **ventricular repolarization**

When ventricles **just** start repolarization (relax), tension developed **just start to decrease** (ventricular pressure **just start to decrease**), **<u>BUT pressure of ventricle still greater than that of aorta</u>** ⇒ Still systole (late systole) / ejection

19-20 HS2 Q22.question: Which of the following correctly ranks pressures during isovolumetric ventricular contraction of a normal cardiac cycle?
19-20 HS2 Q22.explanation:
Isovolumetric ventricular contraction ⇒ Ventricles start to contract
Ventricles building up strength, but not yet great enough to eject blood / open the valves
⇒ Pressure of ventricles < Pressure of aorta (aortic valve closed), yet Pressure of ventricle > Pressure of atrium (mitral valve closed)

Note that ventricular volume unchanged = EDV during this period

19-20 HS2 Q54.question: The phase of SA nodal action potentials is produced in part by

options.B: Increased activity of Na<sup>+</sup>/K<sup>+</sup> ATPase pump
options.D: Increased outward movement of positively charged ions
options.E: Funny channels caused by inward movement of positively charged ions

19-20 HS2 Q54.explanation:
![](img/19-20_HS2_Q54_1755682238326.png) | Phase | Ion channel gating | Ion movement | ----- | ----- | ----- | | Phase 4 - Pacemaker potential / Spontaneous depolarization | Funny channels open
T-type Ca2+ channels open | Na+ influx↑
Ca2+ influx↑ | | Phase 0 - Rapid depolarization | L-type Ca2+ channels open | Ca2+ influx↑ | | Phase 3 - Repolarization | K+ channels open | K+ efflux↑ | Note that funny channels are activated by hyperpolarization

20-21 HSII Q41.question: When atria are denervated, approximately what percentage of blood will flow from atria to ventricle?
20-21 HSII Q41.explanation: Atria can still contract even if denervated (myogenic property)

20-21 HSII Q42.question: An increase pressure within the carotid sinus causes
20-21 HSII Q42.explanation:
Increased pressure within carotid sinus
⇒ Detected by baroreceptors
⇒ Cardiovascular center at medulla oblongata
⇒ Parasympathetic↑, Sympathetic↓
⇒ Heart rate↓(Reflex bradycardia)

20-21 HSII Q43.question: Which of the following is true concerning the depolarisation of pacemaker cell?

options.A: The pacemaker cells cannot trigger action potential without sympathetic input
options.B: The phase 3 depolarization of pacemaker potential accounts for the pacemaker’s autorhythmicity
options.C: The depolarisation of pacemaker potential is driven by calcium influx by slow channels
options.D: The pacemaker potential is slower under acetylcholine input
options.E: The decrease in K<sup>+</sup> permeability occurs under parasympathetic input

20-21 HSII Q43.explanation:
A. Pacemaker cells cannot trigger AP without sympathetic input *Incorrect*
Pacemaker cells are able to fire AP **spontaneously** (self-depolarization)

B. Phase 3 depolarization of pacemaker potential *Incorrect*
Pacemaker potential is **Phase 4**

C. Depolarization of pacemaker potential is driven by Ca<sup>2+</sup> influx by slow channels *Incorrect*
**T-type** (transient type) Ca<sup>2+</sup> channels

D. **Pacemaker potential is slower under acetylcholine input *Correct***
Acetylcholine input (Parasympathetic) ⇒ Muscarinic receptors of pacemaker cells ⇒ K<sup>+</sup> efflux↑, Ca<sup>2+</sup> influx↓ ⇒ Hyperpolarize cell and **decreased rate of depolarization**

E. Decrease in K<sup>+</sup> permeability occurs under parasympathetic input *Incorrect*
Parasympathetic input ⇒ **Increase** in K<sup>+</sup> permeability
See above option

21-22 HSII Q45.question: Which of the following statements correctly describe the arterial baroreceptor reflexes in the regulation of mean arterial pressure?

options.A: The baroreceptor reflexes are short term regulators of arterial pressure that does not adapt to a maintained change in pressure.
options.B: The firing rates of the arterial baroreceptors are inversely proportional to mean arterial pressure.
options.C: The firing rates of the arterial baroreceptors are proportional to pulse pressure.
options.D: The primary integrator centre for the baroreceptor reflexes is located in the hypothalamus.
options.E: When the arterial baroreceptors increase their rate of discharge, the result is a rise in sympathetic activity and a fall in parasympathetic activity.

21-22 HSII Q45.explanation:
A. Baroreceptor reflexes do not adapt to a maintained (sustained) change in pressure *Incorrect*
Only respond to **sudden change** in MAP ⇒ will adapt

B. Firing rates are inversely proportional to MAP *Incorrect*
Positively correlated
Elevated MAP ⇒ Frequency↑
Reduced MAP ⇒ Frequency↓

C. **Firing rates are proportional to PP *Correct***
PP = Systolic pressure - Diastolic pressure
If MAP unchanged, PP↑ (SP↑, DP↓)
⇒ Firing rate will also **increase**

D. Primary integrator centre for the baroreceptor reflexes is located in the hypothalamus *Incorrect*
Should be **medulla oblongata**

E. Increased firing rates, rise in sympathetic activity and fall in parasympathetic activity *Incorrect*
MAP↑ ⇒ Increased rate of discharge of arterial baroreceptors
By negative feedback, 
Parasympathetic↑ and Sympathetic↓
⇒ MAP↓

21-22 HSII Q46.question: Which of the following would speed up the depolarisation rate of the pacemaker potential in the sinoatrial node?

options.A: Increase in influx of calcium ion
options.B: Increase in influx of potassium ion
options.C: Increase in influx of sodium ion
options.D: Increase in outflux of potassium ion
options.E: Increase in outflux of both sodium and calcium ions

21-22 HSII Q46.explanation:
Norepinephrine bind to β<sub>1</sub>-adrenergic receptors that results in the
1. ↑Na<sup>+</sup> influx (Initial period)
2. ↑Ca<sup>2+</sup> influx (Latter period, **depolarize to threshold**)

to speed up rate of depolarization (faster achieve threshold)

*Best solution: Increase in influx of both Na<sup>+</sup> and Ca<sup>2+</sup>*

22-23 HSII Q18.question: A saleswoman stands in the counter for eight hours. She starts to feel like she wants to faint. Which is the most probable reason?
22-23 HSII Q18.explanation:
* **A: *Correct***
Decreased skeletal muscle pump
⇒ Blood pools in the veins
⇒ Venous return↓
⇒ CO↓
⇒ Perfusion to brain cells↓
⇒ Fainting

* B, C, E: *Incorrect*
These options will enhance venous return
Respiratory pump: Inspiration ⇒ P<sub>inter-thoracic</sub>↓ ⇒ P<sub>RA</sub>↓ ⇒ (P<sub>venous</sub> - P<sub>RA</sub>)↑ ⇒ VR↑
(Also P<sub>abdominal</sub>↑ ⇒ Thoracic suction to improve  venous return)
Reduced venous compliance ⇒ Venous pressure↑ ⇒ VR↑
Increased vasoconstriction ⇒ TPR↑ ⇒ MAP↑

* D: *Incorrect*
Not related

22-23 HSII Q19.question:
Which of the following about heart rate is correct?

i. If a person lacks autonomic innervation, the heart rate will be higher than normal.

ii. Heart rate is increased by muscarinic cholinergic nerve action.

iii. Heart rate is increased by beta 1 adrenergic neuronal action.

iv. Rapid depolarization phase of SA action potential determines the heart rate.
22-23 HSII Q19.explanation:
i. **Lacking autonomic innervation leads to higher heart rate *Correct***
Heart normally receives more parasympathetic than sympathetic supply at rest. ⇒ HR = 70-80 AP/min (sinus rhythm)
If lack innervation ⇒ SA node at inherent / inborn rate ⇒ HR = 100 beats/min

ii. HR is increased by muscarinic cholinergic nerve action *Incorrect*
Ach ⇒ Muscarinic cholinergic receptors ⇒ HR↓ (Parasympathetic↑)

iii. **HR is increased by β<sub>1</sub>-adrenergic neuronal action *Correct***
Noradrenaline ⇒ β<sub>1</sub>
-adrenergic receptors ⇒ HR↑ (Sympathetic↑)

iv. Rapid depolarization phase of SA action potential determines HR *Incorrect*
**Slow depolarization** (Phase 4) determines HR

22-23 HSII Q20.question: Which of the following regarding baroreceptors is correct?

options.A: Baroreceptors are located in carotid sinus, aorta, and medulla
options.B: Baroreceptor firing frequency is inversely proportional to MAP
options.C: Baroreceptor reflex is a short-term regulator of arterial pressure
options.D: Baroreceptors respond to any change in pressure and rapidly adjust
options.E: Increase in baroreceptor firing increases sympathetic neuronal activity

22-23 HSII Q20.explanation:
A. Baroreceptors are located in medulla *Incorrect*
Locations: carotid sinus, aortic arch (aorta)
Integrating center: cardiovascular center of medulla oblongata

B. Baroreceptor firing frequency is inversely proportional to MAP *Incorrect*
MAP↑ ⇒ Baroreceptor firing rate↑

C. **Baroreceptor reflex is a short-term regulator of arterial pressure *Correct***
Short-term regulation: Baroreceptor reflex (respond to sudden change in arterial pressure)
Long-term regulation: Kidney

D. Baroreceptors respond to any change in pressure *Incorrect*
Baroreceptors detect **sudden** change
Long-term changes ⇒ Cannot detect and will be adapted

E. Increase in baroreceptor firing increases sympathetic neuronal activity *Incorrect*
Increase in baroreceptor firing ⇒ MAP↑
Medulla oblongata detect increase in firing rate
⇒ Parasympathetic↑, Sympathetic↓
⇒ Vasodilation (arterioles + veins), Cardiac (ventricular) contractility↓, HR and conduction velocity↓
⇒ MAP↓ and back to normal range

22-23 HSII Q21.question: Which of the following correctly describes the events in the ECG, left ventricle, and aorta during a cardiac cycle?

options.A: When blood flows into the aorta during ventricular ejection, the aortic pressure increases along with ventricular pressure
options.B: The volume remaining in the left ventricle after ventricular ejection is called end-diastolic volume
options.C: The atrial pressure does not fluctuate during the cardiac cycle
options.D: The onset of ventricular contraction coincides with the initial vibration of the second heart sound
options.E: The onset of ventricular contraction coincides with the P wave of ECG

22-23 HSII Q21.explanation:
A. **When blood flows into the aorta during ventricular ejection, the aortic pressure increases along with ventricular pressure *Correct***
During ventricular ejection, 
Ventricle still contracting ⇒ Ventricular pressure↑
When ventricular pressure > aortic pressure, aortic valve open ⇒ Blood flows into the aorta ⇒ Aortic pressure↑

B. Volume remaining in the LV after ventricular ejection is called end-diastolic volume *Incorrect*
Ventricular ejection ⇒ Systole ⇒ The volume is called **end-systolic volume (ESV)**

C. Atrial pressure does not fluctuate during the cardiac cycle *Incorrect*
Atria contract to maximize the EDV ⇒ Atrial pressure fluctuates
Note that as blood flows into the atria, atrial pressure increases

D. Onset of ventricular contraction coincides with the initial vibration of the second heart sound *Incorrect*
Onset of ventricular ejection ⇒ AV valves closure ⇒ First heart sound (lub)
Onset of isovolumetric relaxationn ⇒ Semilunar valves closure ⇒ Second heart sound (dub)

E. Onset of ventricular contraction coincides with the P wave of ECG *Incorrect*
P wave ⇒ Atrial depolarization ⇒ Atrial contraction
QRS complex ⇒ Ventricular depolarization ⇒ Ventricular contraction

![](img/22-23_HSII_Q21_1755764682532.png)

23-24 HSII Q9.question: Which of the following events occurs immediately after the start of the QRS complex:
23-24 HSII Q9.explanation:
QRS complex ⇒ Ventricular depolarization

**Immediately** after start of ventricular depolarization, ventricular muscles **start** generate force / building up strength, but force is not large enough to eject blood (P<sub>ventricle</sub> < P<sub>aorta</sub>, considering left ventricle)
⇒ Pressure not high enough to push aortic valve open
⇒ Volume of ventricle unchanged

Note that ventricular ejection occurs **after** the QRS complex

23-24 HSII Q10.question:
Which of the following descriptions about the SA node is correct:

i. SA node contracts faster without parasympathetic control

ii. Rate of firing of SA node is stimulated by binding to muscarinic receptor

iii. Rate of firing of SA node is stimulated by binding to beta-1 adrenergic receptor

iv. Rate of rapid depolarisation determines heart rate
23-24 HSII Q10.explanation:
i. SA node contracts faster without parasympathetic control *Incorrect*
SA node does not contract
Instead, SA node **fires AP** at a higher rate without parasympathetic control

ii. Rate of firing of SA node is stimulated by binding to muscarinic receptor *Incorrect*
Muscarinic receptor ⇒ Acetylcholine ⇒ Parasympathetic
⇒ K<sup>+</sup> efflux↑, Ca<sup>2+</sup> influx↓ ⇒ Hyperpolarize cell, rate of depolarization↓
⇒ Rate of firing of SA node **inhibited**

iii. **Rate of firing of SA node is stimulated by binding to β<sub>1</sub>-adrenergic receptor *Correct***
β<sub>1</sub>-adrenergic receptor ⇒ Noradrenaline ⇒ Sympathetic
⇒ Ca<sup>2+</sup> and Na<sup>+</sup> influx↑ ⇒ Rate of depolarization↑
⇒ Rate of firing of SA node **stimulated**

iv. Rate of rapid depolarization determines heart rate *Incorrect*
Rate of **slow depolarization / spontaneous depolarization / pacemaker potential (Phase 4)** determines heart rate
