(Modified by the ANS ⇒ Acetylcholine & Noradrenaline)

23-24 HSII Q11.question: Which of the following descriptions about baroreceptors are correct?

options.A: They are located at carotid sinus, aorta and medulla
options.B: Their firing rate is inversely proportional to MAP
options.C: Short term regulator of arterial and venous pressure
options.D: Respond to any pressure change and responds to bring pressure back to normal
options.E: Increase in baroreceptor firing will increase sympathetic activity

23-24 HSII Q11.explanation:
A. They are located in medulla *Incorrect*
Locations: carotid sinus, aortic arch (aorta)
Integrating center: cardiovascular center of medulla oblongata

B. Their firing rate is inversely proportional to MAP *Incorrect*
MAP↑ ⇒ Baroreceptor firing rate↑
Note if MAP unchanged but pulse pressure↑ (SP↑, DP↓)
⇒ Firing rate also increases

C. **Short-term regulator of arterial and venous pressure *Correct***
Short-term regulation: Baroreceptor reflex (respond to sudden change in arterial pressure)
Long-term regulation: Kidney

D. Respond to any pressure change *Incorrect*
Baroreceptors detect **sudden** change
Long-term changes ⇒ Cannot detect and will be adapted

E. Increase in baroreceptor firing increases sympathetic activity *Incorrect*
Increase in baroreceptor firing ⇒ MAP↑
Medulla oblongata detect increase in firing rate
⇒ Parasympathetic↑, Sympathetic↓
⇒ Vasodilation (arterioles + veins), Cardiac (ventricular) contractility↓, HR and conduction velocity↓
⇒ HR↓, SV↓, TPR↓
⇒ MAP↓ and back to normal range

23-24 HSII Q12.question: Normal rate of SA node firing without parasympathetic control:
23-24 HSII Q12.explanation:
Note that when body at rest, heart receives more parasympathetic than sympathetic supply
⇒ Slightly inhibit SA node firing
⇒ 70-80 AP/min (sinus rhythm)

Without parasympathetic control
⇒ 100 beats/min (inherent / inborn rate of SA node)

21-22 HSII Q43.question: Which of the following statements is correct concerning the depolarisation of SA node?

options.A: Cell will not depolarise until it receives sympathetic stimulation
options.B: The intrinsic rate of depolarisation in phase 3 accounts for its automaticity
options.C: Pacemaker potential is caused by Ca<sup>2+</sup> entry through slow channels
options.D: Pacemaker potential is slower in achieving threshold when Ach is applied to SA cells
options.E: The permeability of SA node to K<sup>+</sup> ion channels decreases upon parasympathetic stimulation

21-22 HSII Q43.explanation:
A. Cell will not depolarize without sympathetic stimulation *Incorrect*
Pacemaker cells are able to fire AP **spontaneously** (self-depolarization)

B. Intrinsic rate of depolarization in phase 3 *Incorrect*
Pacemaker potential is **Phase 4**

C. Ca<sup>2+</sup> entry through slow channels *Incorrect*
**T-type** (transient type) Ca<sup>2+</sup> channels

D. **Pacemaker potential is slower under acetylcholine input *Correct***
Acetylcholine input (Parasympathetic) ⇒ Muscarinic receptors of pacemaker cells ⇒ K<sup>+</sup> efflux↑, Ca<sup>2+</sup> influx↓ ⇒ Hyperpolarize cell and **decreased rate of depolarization**

E. Decrease in K<sup>+</sup> permeability occurs under parasympathetic input *Incorrect*
Parasympathetic input ⇒ **Increase** in K<sup>+</sup> permeability
See above option

21-22 HSII Q44.question: The T wave of ECG begins to occur during
21-22 HSII Q44.explanation:
T wave of ECG represent **ventricular repolarization**

When ventricles **just** start repolarization (relax), tension developed **just start to decrease** (ventricular pressure **just start to decrease**), **<u>BUT pressure of ventricle still greater than that of aorta</u>** ⇒ Still systole (late systole) / ejection

14-15 MEDU2400 Test Q4.question: Which of the following procedures would most likely bring the resting membrane potential of a typical neuron to near-zero millivolt instantaneously?

options.A: Blocking conductance channels for K+ and opening conductance channels for Na+
options.C: Replacing extracellular NaCl with the same molar concentration of choline (a non-permeable cation) chloride
options.D: Replacing extracellular NaCl with the same molar concentration of KCl
options.E: Replacing extracellular NaCl with the same molar concentration of Na2SO4 (a less permeable anion)

14-15 MEDU2400 Test Q4.explanation:
A. This removes the influence of K+ to membrane potential, and pull it very close to equilibrium potential of Na+ instead, which is around +60 mV.
 B. There will be a slight depolarization only, not sufficient to a near-zero value.
 C. The RMP would probably be raised slightly as K+ moves out of the cell until it equilibrates itself. Contribution from Cl- is very low.
 D. Extracellular [Na+] is very similar to intracellular [K+] so if the Na+ turns into K then almost no gradient → RMP mainly determined by K+ so it can bring it to near-zero mV
 E. The major cations are the same. No matter how it changes, it would not be as significant as D.

18-19 MEDU2400 Test Q21.question: Which of the following leads to hypokalemia?
18-19 MEDU2400 Test Q21.explanation:
A. In acidemia / acidosis, the high extracellular H+ ion concentration would displace intracellular K+, leading to hyperkalemia (for intracellular protein buffering; more in renal physiology)
 B. Excess thyroid hormone stimulates the activity of sodium potassium pump, which causes an excess reuptake of potassium ions from the extracellular fluid and leads to hypokalemia.
 C. Chemotherapy = Cell lysis = burst of intracellular K+ to the outside → Hyperkalemia
 D. At most, prolonged K+ efflux during the repolarization phase raises ECF K+ and causes hyperkalemia / muscle weakness.

Other factors that lead to
 * Hypokalemia: insulin, beta-adrenergic agonists, aldosterone
 * Hyperkalemia: Exercise, beta-adrenergic antagonists, ouabain / digoxin (inhibiting Na+/K+ ATPase)

19-20 MEDU2400 Test Q21.question: Lowering threshold of potential when generation of action potential
19-20 MEDU2400 Test Q21.explanation:
This question is actually put in the wrong category. Yet, this is best to let you integrate concepts.
Note that the question talks about THRESHOLD, not excitability.

 A. Axon diameter is proportional to the velocity of action potential propagation.
B. Reducing extracellular calcium = hypocalcemia, which reduces the accommodation effect of calcium. This lowers the threshold of excitation. The shielding effect is due to the high charge density of calcium that makes it tend to bind with the negatively charged chloride ions that passively distribute across the surface of the membrane. Thus, the presence of calcium alters the gating properties of the voltage-gated channels on the membrane, and raises the threshold of excitation.
 C. The stimulus is coded by frequency, but not the threshold.
 D. Lowering K+ permeability will make the RMP away from equilibrium potential of K+, giving a hyperpolarisation. In the short term it won’t affect the threshold, but in the long run it will increase open-state as less Na+ channels are inactivated.
 E. For option E, raising extracellular K+ = hyperkalemia, which helps depolarize the cell / bring the RMP closer to threshold. In other words, the EXCITABILITY increases.

20-21 MEDU2400 Test Q21.question:
| | extracellular conc. | intracellular conc. |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Ca2+ | 2.5 | 10^(-4) |
| K+ | 4 | 140 |
| Na+ | 140 | 7 |
| Cl- | 7 | 110 |

Given that membrane potential = -70mV, which ion has the highest flow rate?
20-21 MEDU2400 Test Q21.explanation: Note that at equilibrium, K+ efflux + Cl- influx = Na+ influx + Ca2+ influx. The relative flow can be estimated from conductance and driving force of each ion. However, we do not have any information about conductance of Ca2+ to estimate its flow. So, I think this question is simply asking which ion has the greatest driving force, i.e. greatest distance of its equilibrium potential from the RMP –70mV. This question will make sense if all ions have the same conductance for free flow, which is not the case in vivo.

16-17 MEDU2400 Test Q21.question: Which of the following can lower the threshold?

options.C: Prolong increase in K extra concentration

16-17 MEDU2400 Test Q21.explanation:
**Shielding effect of Ca2+**
Note that there are static negative charges on the surface of the cell membrane due to phospholipid molecules.
Divalent ions like Ca2+ have higher charge density and are more attracted to the surface negative charges than those monovalent ions.
Hypercalcaemia increases threshold by shielding effect.
 * Ca2+ binds to the negative charge → alter electric field within membrane
 * Gating properties of channels altered (e.g. Ca2+ increase → Reduce Na+ channel opening tendency)  → Raise threshold potential

17-18 MEDU2400 Test Q21.question: Which of the following can lower the threshold of action potential?

17-18 MEDU2400 Test Q22.question: When a current is injected to a point in the middle of the axon of motor neuron to produce suprathreshold stimulation, which of the following represents the most likely findings?

options.A: There is only depolarisation at the site of needle insertion, but no propagation of AP
options.B: The AP is not propagated back to soma
options.C: Can be detected in all regions of the neuron
options.D: Can be detected in all regions of axon
options.E: The amplitude of action potential is increasing towards the trigger zone(?)

17-18 MEDU2400 Test Q22.explanation:
This is a pretty tricky question.
Usually, we say that the transmission of electrical signals along a neuron is unidirectional, as ensured by the refractory periods.
However, if the depolarization is initiated in the middle of the neuron, the voltage-gated sodium channels in both directions are NOT inactivated, which means that when the receptors on either side detect a rise in membrane potential above threshold, they will open. Thus, action potential spreads along the entire axon.

20-21 MEDU2400 Final Q0.question: Which of the following will cause hypokalemia? (Choices reconstructed)
20-21 MEDU2400 Final Q0.explanation:
Only option A is a new option. The others are the same as the previous questions.

 A. Choice A is made up as it is lost from source. Propranolol as a non-selective beta blocker, it will block β2 receptors on body cells as well. This inhibits activity of Na+/K+-ATPase to transport K+ from ECF into ICF, and causes hyperkalemia.
 B. Incorrect, as ECF H+ displaces ICF K+ for buffering and causes hyperkalemia.
 C. Correct, as this stimulates the activity of NA+/K+ ATPase.
 D. D is a bit controversial, as it depends on type I or II. For type I, the absence of insulin will lower activity of Na+/K+-ATPase and cause hyperkalemia similar to beta blocker. However, for type II, the normal or even higher insulin level will do the opposite and cause hypokalemia. This is because in type II DM, insulin secretion is normal and it is insulin resistance causing the inability to lower blood glucose to normal range. Always keep in mind physiology and biochemistry are almost inseparable, and it is important to link concepts in different courses to get the whole picture.
 E. Incorrect, as prolonged K+ efflux in the repolarization phase increases ECF K+.

18-19 MEDU2400 Test Q23.question: Which of the following best describes the classification of baroreceptor?
18-19 MEDU2400 Test Q23.explanation: Conditioned reflex refers to those acquired through learning, e.g. walking and playing piano. You can’t voluntarily control each finger movement for each note, it is a string of conditioned reflexes to precisely control each movement before you realize. Spinal vs cranial refers to the position of control center, and of course baroreceptor reflex works at NTS, CVLM (Integration), NA (PSNS output), RVLM (SNS output) at the medulla oblongata. Knee jerk reflex is the only example of disynaptic reflex. Somatic vs visceral refers to the effector of reflex being skeletal muscle or viscera.

21-22 MEDU2400 Test Q22.question: In a spinal surgery, a man has several lumbar dorsal root injuries. He has a decreased muscle tone and experiences difficulty to stand upright. Which of the following is most likely to be damaged to cause his condition?

21-22 MEDU2400 Test Q22.explanation:
Read this if you like. I would just memorize the answer.
A will cause hyporeflexia. B is a more interesting case, as it has two possible causes you will learn. The first cause is Clostridium tetani infection (HUF1 General Physiology), which causes tetanospasmin (Toxin from bacteria) to enter via wound and reaches the inhibitory interneurons in spinal cord. This will degrade synaptobrevin to inhibit release of inhibitory neurotransmitters from them to cause full contraction in all muscles innervated by affected spinal levels. Another cause is upper motor neuron lesion (UMN lesion, HUS2 Neuroanatomy), as UMN synapses to the inhibitory interneurons to inhibit reflex. Although the initial hyperreflexia is caused by absence of input to inhibitory neurons, however, in later stage the degeneration of UMN reduces the neurotrophic factors released to inhibitory interneurons, causing their degeneration too. It will cause spasm as absence of inhibition causes constant contraction of skeletal muscle. UMN lesion further causes paralysis as it will innervate LMN to voluntarily control the muscles. C is correct as said before. D is similar but wrong. Although sensory neurons from Golgi tendon organ also participate in limb coordination, but its contribution is much less important than muscle spindles. Its main use is to elicit Golgi tendon reflex to prevent overstretching of muscles. Again, E is the LMN lesion which will cause flaccid paralysis, as the absence of LMN supply to skeletal muscles simply make them cannot contract.

20-21 MEDU2400 Sem1 Q31.question: Which of the following contributes to the major ion current in pacemaker cells?
20-21 MEDU2400 Sem1 Q31.explanation:
This question is very ambiguous. 
This question appeared the second time in the 2223 test, and it is not recited in the wrong way. 

An email response from Prof. Au: 
The teacher who set this question tried to help students by putting in weird options. If you have not heard of any “long lasting K+ channel” and “transient Na+ channel” in the lecture, sure they do not exist. The teacher is trying to “paint a wrong picture with the intestine shown” (Chinese proverb). He has not spelt out T-type Ca channel” as “transient opening calcium channel” and L-type Ca channel as “long-lasting calcium channel” as he knows the students would surely understand what they are even with the use of abbreviations. For the wrong options, he has to spell out the long form to make it more convincing as a distractor. 

So, option A & D can be filtered out directly. 
Funny current = Na+ influx by HCN channels (hyperpolarization cyclic-nucleotide-gated Na+ channels); voltage-gated Na+ channels are not involved. 
T-type Ca2+ channels only contribute a minor part in late phase 4; 
So, LTCC contributes the major ion current in pacemaker cells if we only have these 5 options. 
In case voltage-gated K+ channels also appear in the options, good luck.

20-21 MEDU2400 Final Q7.question: Which of the following is primarily dependent on a normal AV nodal delay?
20-21 MEDU2400 Final Q7.explanation: AV node has the slowest conduction velocity in the conduction system. As the atria contract after the electrical signal propagates from SA node to AV node via atrial cardiomyocytes, the AV nodal delay allows time for atrial systole to take place. This ensures that sufficient time is given for blood to fill the ventricle before the electrical signal is relayed to ventricles with increasing speed (This explains the question below).

21-22 MEDU2400 Final Q8.question: A man with dysrhythmia is referred for further examination to identify potential abnormalities in cardiac electrical conduction. Which of the following sites in a normal heart should exhibit the fastest rate of electrical conductance?
21-22 MEDU2400 Final Q8.explanation:
Generally speaking, the conduction rate in the heart conduction system increases from SA node along to Purkinje fibers, except that AV node has the slowest rate given its small radius and low density of gap junctions. 

Reference Values: (Conduction velocity) (Taken from Ivan’ notes P.5)
Atria: 1 m/s
AV node: 0.01-0.05 m/s
Purkinje Fibers: 2-4 m/s
Ventricle: 1 m/s

15-16 MEDU2400 Final Q8.question: Which of the following values are reached or obtained when the aortic valve closes?
15-16 MEDU2400 Final Q8.explanation: When the aortic valve **closes**, it marks the beginning of isovolumetric relaxation and the end of ventricular contraction. Thus, it is ESV that remains in the ventricles.

16-17 MEDU2400 Final Q8.question: Which of the following is reached when the aortic valve opens?
16-17 MEDU2400 Final Q8.explanation:
A. Diastolic pressure refers to the minimal **aortic** pressure reached as the blood drains out of the aorta while the ventricle is still filling up (i.e. attained before ventricular ejection). Thus, the diastolic pressure is attained approximately at the moment when the aortic valve opens (i.e. end of diastole). Pay special attention to the fact that “DIASTOLIC PRESSURE” describes pressure in AORTA, while EDV is a description for the ventricles.
 B. Systolic pressure is the maximal aortic pressure during ventricular contraction. It is obtained **during** ventricular ejection after the aortic valve opens for a while.
 C. EDV is reached **before** the aortic valve opens. It is attained after the ventricular filling phase.
 D. ESV is reached only when the aortic valve closes (beginning of isovolumetric relaxation). Only at that point does blood stop flowing out of the ventricles and remain in it.
 E. Stroke volume = EDV - ESV → Irrelevant to the opening / closure of aortic valve

![](img/16-17_MEDU2400_Final_Q8_1767247768993.jpeg)

17-18 MEDU2400 Test Q31.question: Aortic diastolic pressure is determined primarily by

options.D: Resistance in smaller arteries and arterioles

17-18 MEDU2400 Test Q31.explanation:
B\. aortic pressure at the dicrotic notch (caused by the closure of aortic valve → retrograde blood flow towards aortic valve) ≠ diastolic pressure
The purpose of elastic recoil is to maintain a constant flow in the arteries.
Note that MAP = CO x TPR. Diastolic pressure is thus related to TPR and hence D is the most relevant answer. 

(More Explanations)
Diastolic pressure determines the **afterload** of the heart, i.e. the pressure remaining after previous contraction which needs to be overcome by the next round of contraction. Diastolic pressure is determined by resistance of smaller arteries and arterioles, as they provide most of the resistance in the CV system.
C could contribute to the variation in the drop of blood pressure in different segments of circulation. For example, high elasticity in vessels of young individuals facilitates wall stretching and then recoil to cause pressure amplification across arteries.

The second heart sound is produced by the closure of the aortic and pulmonary valves (semilunar valves) when ventricular ejection begins.

21-22 MEDU2400 Test Q28.question: When is the intraventricular pressure lowest? (Options modified)
21-22 MEDU2400 Test Q28.explanation:
**Intraventricular pressure is lowest at the end of isovolumetric relaxation**, as the pressure will rise again when ventricular filling commences right afterwards.
A is wrong as it is the beginning of isovolumetric relaxation (Same as D), and the pressure is not yet lowest as the ventricle is still in contracted state.
B is wrong as it is the start of isovolumetric contraction (Same as C), which of course has a similar, but still higher pressure than A and D.
"Start of ventricular ejection" is the end of isovolumetric contraction as the ventricular pressure is high enough to exceed the aortic pressure to start ejection. The highest pressure is at the midst of ventricular ejection, as the pressure continues to rise for a short period due to continuous ventricular contraction. The pressure then starts to drop as there is less blood inside the ventricle to maintain it.

![](img/21-22_MEDU2400_Final_Q7_1768627698189.jpeg)
21-22 MEDU2400 Final Q7.explanation:
I would like everyone of you reading this question to give a big round of applaud to Anes 26 who drew these curves. I think it is quite hard to observe the answer without the underlying scales, but this also means if you have them, you have to pick the correct answer. The answer here is 1st degree AV block, which means PR interval exceeds the 0.12 - 0.2s range. You can observe the spacing between the P wave and QRS complex is much further than the QRS complex and T wave. B is false as the transition zone at V3 indicates no abnormality. C is also wrong as according to this scale, it is obviously the PR interval much longer than QT interval. Electrical axis is at around +90 degrees (aVR and aVL both negative indicates between +60 to +120, while lead I is almost equiphasic, so can only be +90), which is also within normal range. E is false as each pulse has a fixed interval (Hard to see here though).

Prof. Simon Au promised to us in the revision session to include everything he taught in his lectures in his only ECG MC, which he really succeeded to do so.

22-23 MEDU2400 Test Q27.question:
In the accompanying ECG, which of the following gives the best estimate of the electrical axis of the heart?
Lead I, II, III, aVL, aVF all positive
Lead III almost equiphasic
22-23 MEDU2400 Test Q27.explanation: Lead III almost equiphasic is quite useless if you ask me, when all the choices are ranges of degrees. However, you could still guess the axis is pretty close to +30 or –150 degrees. From leads I and III both positive, we can narrow down the search into +30 (+150 – 90) to +90 (0 + 90). aVF and lead II must be positive within this range, so the information is useless. Positive aVL then suggests the axis is between –120 to +60, so the axis must be between +30 to +60 degrees. It is very smart to use the word “almost” equiphasic, as it is sometimes hard to observe a perfectly equiphasic QRS complex. Never assume something is equiphasic, especially the choices are all ranges of degrees.

15-16 MEDU2400 Final Q10.question: An increase in mean arterial pressure leads to which of the following:

options.E: no changes to preload or afterload

15-16 MEDU2400 Final Q10.explanation:
Refer to Maggie’s CV Notes P.40//Answer received from Simon Au
Note that an increase in MAP will lead to an increase in aortic pressure, so that afterload is increased as ventricles need to generate more forceful contraction isometrically to push open the aortic valve.
Reduced SV will reduce VR and decrease preload, but it is already several steps further from increased MAP.

16-17 MEDU2400 Test Q27.question: Which of the following relates to the Frank-Starling relationship or Starling law?
16-17 MEDU2400 Test Q27.explanation:
Frank-Starling relationship: Ventricular end-diastolic volume increases (due to increased venous return), leading to an increase in stroke volume.
This can be explained as increased preload will **stretch** the cardiomyocytes towards the optimum length with **more actin-myosin overlapping and interaction (forming maximum number of cross-bridges)**, hence increasing the efficiency of muscle contraction and raising the force of contraction. This is necessary for the heart to increase SV to match the increased VR.
Note that CONTRACTILITY does not increase here, but is the force of contraction / contractile force that increases. This is because contractility is related to intrinsic mechanisms, such as beta-1 stimulation (i.e. relates to calcium influx). Please study P. 13 of Ivan’s notes.

16-17 MEDU2400 Final Q9.question: Which of the following mostly causes a decrease in stroke volume?
16-17 MEDU2400 Final Q9.explanation:
Please refer to Ivan’s notes P. 10.
A. EDV may only be decreased if diastolic filling time is shortened too much

17-18 MEDU2400 Test Q27.question: Which of the following ensures venous return equal cardiac output?
17-18 MEDU2400 Test Q27.explanation:
Bainbridge reflex, also called atrial reflex, is an increase in heart rate due to an increase in central venous pressure. Increased blood volume is detected by stretch receptors (cardiac receptors) located at both sides of the atria at the venoatrial junctions.
The overall response in the heart by the Frank-Starling mechanism is as follows:
1. There is increased central venous pressure = filling pressure of the heart.
2. There are 2 consequences:
	a. By the Frank-Starling relationship, there will be increased right ventricular SV and thus an increased output from the right heart
	b. Venous return is reduced (CVP increase → reduce pressure gradient between veins / venous bed and right atrium → reduce flow)
3. Right output > left output
4. Blood accumulates in the pulmonary vasculature and raises pulmonary venous and left atrial pressures.
5. By the Frank-Starling relationship, increased left atrial pressure increases left ventricular stroke volume.
6. A new steady state is reached, where output from both sides of the heart becomes equal.

19-20 MEDU2400 Final Q13.question: Which of the following represents the most likely reason for a decreased Stroke volume
19-20 MEDU2400 Final Q13.explanation:
A. see (B)
B. refer to 1-35 heart failure p.3
C. decreased EDV → decreased SV
D. decrease afterload → increase SV
E. only decreases SV at very short systole, i.e. not all the blood possible is pumped out after systole

A could be a possible reason but only valid when HR is raised too much. It is worth noting that passive filling contributes 70-80% of EDV. B is also a possible reason given that EDV is constant, as SV = EDV – ESV. C and D should increase SV due to Frank-Starling (C) and decreased resistance for blood flow (D). E is never an option either, as systolic duration is kept rather constant despite increase in HR, it is the diastolic duration being compromised when HR raises, which leads to the option A. However, there is no such factor that will affect ESV primarily, and it is always the EDV (Preload, passive filling) and SV (Afterload, contractility etc.) being varied first. Hence I would prefer A as the answer here, as increased ESV is more likely the consequence of decreased SV, instead of its reason.

20-21 MEDU2400 Sem1 Q32.question: Which of the following mechanisms can increase the cardiac output?
20-21 MEDU2400 Sem1 Q32.explanation:
A. Decreasing the afterload increases SV and hence CO.
 B. Decreasing the preload (EDV) reduces SV and hence CO
 C. Decreasing the venous return reduces EDV and SV and CO by the Frank-Starling relationship
 D. Increasing ACh-activated K+ channels increases the rate of repolarization (hyperpolarization) as well as the duration of phase 2. This is caused by option E.
 E. Increasing parasympathetic stimulation will reduce the HR and hence CO

20-21 MEDU2400 Final Q8.question: Which of the following represent the direct outcome of the Frank-Starling mechanism?

options.A: Increase sympathetic output increase heart rate
options.B: Increase stroke volume due to increase heart rate
options.C: Increase stroke volume due to increase cardiac contractility
options.D: Increase stroke volume due to increase preload
options.E: Increase systolic blood pressure due to increase stroke volume

20-21 MEDU2400 Final Q8.explanation:
By definition, the answer is D. <u>**READ THIS!**</u>
You must remember that the Frank-Starling relationship has nothing to do with cardiac contractility. Some sources suggest that option C is the reason while option D is the direct outcome of the Frank-Starling relationship, but this is not entirely true. Contractility defines the relative ability of the heart to eject a stroke volume **AT A GIVEN AFTERLOAD (arterial pressure / MAP) & PRELOAD (EDV)**! If the Frank-Starling relationship states that EDV is proportional to SV, then the increase in SV cannot be attributed to contractility because EDV is the independent variable now, and hence the definition of contractility does not hold.
To put it simply, just remember that contractility relates to all sorts of intrinsic control mechanisms, while the Frank-Starling relationship can only be described using “force of contraction”.
You can fully understand the length-dependent and length-independent changes in contractile function (≠ contractility).
https://www.cvphysiology.com/Cardiac%20Function/CF003
Again, refer to P.13 of Ivan’s notes.

21-22 MEDU2400 Final Q10.question: A healthy 30-year-old man stand up after you being in a supine position for several hours. Which of the following changes to his cardiovascular response is expected after he stands up for several seconds?
21-22 MEDU2400 Final Q10.explanation:
It would be better to place this question at Integrative Cardiovascular Physiology.
First you should know VR decreases due to gravity, and then SV and MAP drop. Obviously B and E are wrong at this point. Ejection fraction will not be affected by postural changes, but instead slowly decreases in the case of systolic heart failure, which is not the case here (You can’t have significant change in EF within hours).
A is achieved under PSNS stimulation, which is the opposite of this scene, as baroreceptor reflex will take place to restore MAP by increasing SNS output. However, this is not caused by direct innervation, but instead active hyperemia. The positive chronotropic and inotropic effects in the heart will increase its energy consumption and production of vasodilators, e.g. adenosine, H+, K+ etc. The dilation of coronary arteries will lower the resistance, so A is false.
The only answer here is D. Positive inotropy of the heart raises the SP, and therefore raises the PP (SP-DP). Actually, DP can also raise as SNS effect also includes peripheral vasoconstriction, but such effect will increase VR and then SV, so that the increase in SP will be greater than DP, leading to net increase in PP.
This is a pretty interesting question and lets you have a feeling of logical deduction in physiology. Sometimes, different factors will contradict each other, and you will need to justify the results with principles instead. Stick to the given result, and try to weigh out which factor predominates in the setting will be the answer.

21-22 MEDU2400 Final Q11.question:
After applying effective dose of NE, original point X will shift to which point?

![](img/21-22_MEDU2400_Final_Q11_1768628352941.jpeg)
21-22 MEDU2400 Final Q11.explanation: If you are smart, you can spot that the NE dose is similar to SNS stimulation, and you can just copy the graph in lecture slides. Venoconstriction decreases the venous capacitance, so that ECV (Renal physiology concept, i.e. the effective volume of blood in circulation) increases. This raises the VR for any given RAP linearly (Each point increases for the same amount) as there is simply more blood flowing in the circulation, and the curve will shift parallel to the right. For cardiac function curve, the slope will increase as positive inotropy increases the CO for each given RAP (Which also indicates VR and EDV). The flattened part of cardiac function curve indicates the maximum CO possible limited by maximum heart contractility achieved by Frank-Starling mechanism. To sum up, the new point should be on a vascular curve shifted parallel to right, and cardiac curve with higher slope, which is D.

21-22 MEDU2400 Test Q30.question: What is the compliance of a blood vessel?

options.C: Pressure difference between 2 ends of the blood vessels
options.D: Elastic recoil of the blood vessels

21-22 MEDU2400 Test Q30.explanation:
This is a tricky question.
Well, you can just answer A by saying that “this is the definition listed in the lecture slides.” But you better know the reason why the answer is not B.
In fact, vascular compliance can be described by **distensibility** and **elastance** of the blood vessel. Distensibility and elastance are reciprocal of each other. However, elasticity is not an accurate term in this question! It has to be the elastance of a blood vessel to be describing vascular compliance! **No other alternative wordings!**
Remember that elastance and distensibility are terms used in biomedical sciences, while elasticity is a layman term!

If you did not study physics in the past, the equivalent resistance in A is simply the reciprocal of the sum of reciprocals of the parallel resistances [i.e. R = 1 / (⅓ + ⅓ + ⅓ = 1]

16-17 MEDU2400 Final Q15.question: Which of the following substances require the endothelial cells to achieve a vasodilatory effect?
16-17 MEDU2400 Final Q15.explanation:
For option A, the following is the whole process of how **ACh leads to vasodilation with NO from endothelial cells**.
1. ACh requires endothelial cells to achieve vasodilation. ACh binds with M3 receptors and triggers the Gq protein pathway. PLC activation → DAG + IP3
	* DAG → Receptor-operated Ca2+ channels (ROC) open
	* IP3 → IP3R → IP3-gated Calcium channel release Ca2+ from SERCA (intracellular store)
		* With a depletion of intracellular calcium store, store-operated Ca2+ channels also open
2. Overall, intracellular calcium of the ENDOTHELIAL CELLS is increased. Try not to mix up the calcium influx and efflux in VSMC with the things happening here.
3. As a result, nitric oxide synthesis is promoted as high intracellular calcium concentration stimulates the activity of eNOS by the formation of Ca-calmodulin complex. (Under eNOS, L-arginine + O2 → NO + citrulline)
4. NO diffuses from endothelial cells to VSMC, and triggers the cGMP/ PKG pathway (soluble guanylyl cyclase → cGMP → PKG).
5. There are 2 pathways by which the cGMP/PKG pathway leads to vasodilation
	* Opening of BK channels → hyperpolarization → closure of LTCC
	* Increased activity of SERCA & PMCA

However, note that ACh can also act on M3 receptors on VSMC to elicit vasoconstriction via the Gq pathway. This is because the surge in Ca2+ will trigger cross-bridge cycle in VSMC.

For option B, ANP is an antagonist to aldosterone. It can lead to vasodilation by increasing water excretion in kidneys.
For option C, the drug there is a potassium channel opener, which DIRECTLY leads to hyperpolarization of cells and hence vasodilation.
For option D, nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker. It reduces intracellular calcium by blocking LTCC DIRECTLY.
For option E, the drug mentioned is a NO donor, so endothelium is not involved in the synthesis of NO and the related vasodilatory effects.

18-19 MEDU2400 Final Q13.question: endothelium-derived substance inhibited by superoxide anion

options.D: nitric oxide and reactive oxygen species

18-19 MEDU2400 Final Q13.explanation:
NO is the endothelium-derived vasodilator that helps to reduce MAP. As it carries an unpaired electron, it will react with ROS to break down into more stable molecules, hence its effect is inhibited by ROS. This may explain why increased oxidative stress (e.g. due to aging, smoking) will decrease the vasodilatory effect of NO, hence increasing the risk of developing hypertension.
You may refer to the details in the following website.
https://www.cvphysiology.com/Blood%20Flow/BF016

21-22 MEDU2400 Test Q31.question: Which of the following about prostacyclin is correct?

options.A: It triggers vasodilation by increasing cytosolic [cAMP] in vascular smooth muscle cells.
options.B: It is formed from L-arginine via cyclooxygenase pathway.
options.C: It acts by blocking K+ channels on endothelial cells.
options.D: It acts by blocking Ca2+ channels on vascular smooth muscle cells.
options.E: It acts by increasing cytosolic [Ca2+] in endothelial cells.

21-22 MEDU2400 Test Q31.explanation:
A. Correct. PGI2 binds to its receptor coupled with adenylate cyclase, then cAMP activates PKA to phosphorylate MLCK into its inactive form to prevent cross-bridge cycling. PKA also phosphorylates a series of different target transporters to bring about smooth muscle relaxation, and you can almost assume Gs receptors are linked to muscle relaxation.
B. This describes NO.
C. C is false as PKA activates BK channels to cause K+ efflux and hyperpolarisation.
D. D is false as calcium channels in VSMC are closed due to hyperpolarisation, instead of direct inhibition by PGI2. However, direct block can be achieved by dihydropyridine class of calcium channel blocker, e.g. amlodipine.
E. E is false as this is performed by ACh and storage-gated Ca2+ channels instead.

21-22 MEDU2400 Final Q15.question: A substance is found to diminish vascular smooth muscle contraction but without any effect on ventricular muscle contraction. Which of the following represents the most likely site of action of this substance?
21-22 MEDU2400 Final Q15.explanation: This vasodilator is most likely acting on mechanisms leading to muscle relaxation, yet not related to cardiac muscle. But before we start, make sure you know there is **no troponin in smooth muscle**, as calmodulin takes up the part as Ca sensor already. Tropomyosin is still present to regulate actin-myosin interaction, but not as the same way in skeletal muscle, i.e. blocking actin-binding site on myosin. The exact mechanism is outsyl, but you still need to know it still has a regulatory role. A and C are clearly wrong as β1 receptors control inotropy and chronotropy of the heart, while PKA is involved in signal transduction of β1 stimulation. The answer left is calmodulin. The drug could be potentiating the effect of Ca-calmodulin complex to produce even more vasodilators under Ca2+ stimulation.

Extra MEDU2400 CV Q8.explanation:
A. NE on α1/α2 receptors, endothelin on ETAR/ETBR and angiotensin II on AT1R are constricting agonists that can lead to elevated calcium level in VSMC. (In fact, we usually only refer to α1, ETA and AT1 receptors)
B. PGF2a &PGH2 are vasoconstrictors in the endothelium.
C. Gs protein does not activate phospholipase C.
D. β-agonists, adenosine and vasoactive intestinal peptide can act on receptors to stimulate adenylate cyclase, in which an increase in production in cAMP and activation of PKA leads to hyperpolarization.
E. Ca2+ and K+ should be interchanged in this statement.
